7th March, 1949.

Mr. E.S. Jones,
Superintendent, Indian Agency,
P.O. Box 787,
Prince Albert, Saskatchewan.

We have your letter of the 23rd ultimo enclosing applications for admission and certificates of health for the admission of Florence and Grace Bird to the St. Alban's Residential School.

It is noted that these girls came from Montreal Lake Reserve, where one of the girls has attended the day school for six months and the other for fifteen months. Both parents are stated to be living, and consequently, before approving their admission we would like to know if there are any special reasons why these girls should receive institutional care. From the information contained in the forms it would appear that they should continue to attend the Montreal Lake Day School. As you know, it is not our practice to place children in residential schools when they come from a reserve where a day school is in operation, unless there are some particular reasons why they should be removed from their homes.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Education Division

Ottawa, October 30, 1947.

Dear General Turner:

We have your letter of the 25th inst., file P.A.-3 with reference to transportation of children to and from Indian residential schools.

Sub-section 3 of Section 9 of the Indian Act reads in part as follows:

"The Superintendent General (Minister) may provide for the transport of Indian children, etc..."

You will note that payment of such expenses is not compulsory.

The general practice for many years is that principals of residential schools and Indian Agents are expected to encourage parents to bring the children to the school and to return them to their homes without cost either to the Department or the school management.

However, in cases where the above mentioned action is not practicable, we are prepared to consider making an allowance towards the travelling expenses. However, in such cases principals are expected to advise the Indian Agent what amount they consider could be required to cover travelling expenses and the Agent in turn applies to the Department. We can then decide the amount that we can allow.

We are only allowed a limited amount for the transportation of pupils to and from residential schools and consequently we try to deal fairly with all schools by keeping the expenditure to the lowest possible point.

Yours sincerely,

19th May, 1949.

Mr. E.S. Jones,
Superintendent, Indian Agency,
Prince Albert, Saskatchewan.

We have recently received a request from Canon Cook, Superintendent of the M.S.C.C., for an amount of $375.00, the estimated cost of transporting children from St. Alban's Residential School to their homes at the end of the present term. Canon Cook does not state whether the above amount covers their transportation home and also the return of the pupils to school after the summer holidays.

In requesting the above amount Canon Cook refers to a letter from the Department dated October 30th, 1947, a copy of which is attached for your information. In replying to Canon Cook we have suggested to him that the Principal of St. Alban's follow the procedure outlined in the fourth paragraph of official letter of October 30th, 1947, by consulting you.

May I direct your attention to the fact that the amount provided for travelling expenses is limited, and as we try to deal fairly with all residential schools, we must be very careful deciding what amount we can allow to each one of them.

June 20th, 1949.

Mr. E.S. Jones,
Superintendent, Indian Agency,
Box 787, Prince Albert, Sask.

We have your letter of the 4th instant with reference to the pupils returning to their homes for the summer holidays in the St. Albin's and Lac la Ronge Indian Residential Schools.

We presume that the Principal and yourself have made every possible effort to secure the transportation expenses from the parents. You will recall that instructions to this effect were contained in official letter of May 19th.

In connection with that portion of the expenses that is not paid by the parents, it has always been our practice to expect the school management to co-operate with us by paying a portion of the cost.

After considering the contents of your letter, I consulted the officials of the Head Office of the M.S.C.C., and it has been decided that the Department will allow the following amounts for the summer of 1949:

(1) St. Albin's - $200.00
(2) Lac la Ronge - $575.00

With reference to the last paragraph of your letter, we sent you an army signal this afternoon.

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education

Your File No. 403-11-1-6 (107)

We have your letter of the 21st instant and it is noted that you have now advised Superintendent Law that the children of Manitoba may return to the Lac la Ronge School after the summer holidays.

It appears that the most feasible manner of settling the difficulty is to have Mr. Mayo, principal of Gordon's School interview the principals of Lac la Ronge and St. Alban's Schools in order to ascertain the names and number of the children from the John Smith's and James Smith's Reserves who might be transferred from Lac la Ronge and St. Alban's to the Gordon Residential School. Mr. Mayo could then take up the matter with Superintendent N.J. McLeod of the Duck Lake Agency in order that he may make arrangements with the children concerned.

When these details have been completed a letter should be forwarded to us giving the names and register numbers of the children transferred from the St. Alban's and Lac la Ronge Schools to the Gordon's School.

If this is handled properly it will provide vacancies for children from Northern Saskatchewan.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Education Division.

We are in receipt of applications for the admission of Margaret Winnifred Cook, Louis Arthur Bear and Gerald Howard Bear to the Prince Albert Residential School. Dear Colonel Neary:

Re: Transportation of children for holidays, Anglican Indian Residential Schools, Prince Albert, Sask.

In your letter 658-10 (E.l) of 20th June, 1949, you informed us that you would allow the following amounts for travelling expenses of pupils going on holidays:

(1) St. Alban's (Onion Lake) School $200.00
(2) All Saints' (Lac la Ronge) School $575.00

Subsequently we sent you accounts covering the transportation of pupils to their homes following the close of the term in June, 1949, as under:

St. Alban's $119.24
All Saints' $457.12

leaving unexpended balances of $30.76 and $117.88 for St. Alban's and All Saints' respectively.

We now have received accounts for travelling expenses of pupils returning to or joining these Schools for the autumn, 1949, term as follows:

St. Alban's $115.38
All Saints' $365.11

Deducing the credits mentioned above, the following additional amounts are still required to cover the cost of return and joining transportation expenses:

St. Alban's $115.38 less $80.76 = $34.62
All Saints' $365.11 less $117.88 = $247.23

$281.85

In view of the fact that the accounts now received cover

(P.T.O.)
the cost of transporting a number of new pupils joining the Schools for the first time it will be appreciated if you will accept the charges of $281.85 detailed above in addition to the amounts indicated in your 658-10 (E.L.) of 20th June, 1949. Yours sincerely,

Henry G. Cook,

I wish to acknowledge receipt of your letter of August 31st, 1949 under file 658-10 (El), with regard to Applications for Admission of Margaret Winnifred Cook, Louis Arthur Bear and Gerald Howard Bear to the Prince Albert Residential School, and regret delay in answering same.

With regard to Margaret Winnifred Cook, I would advise that this application was submitted due to the fact that the parents of this child refused to send her to the Big Eddy School as discipline is very lax and the child was not making any progress. Both parents although they would like to have the child at home requested that she be admitted to Residential School.

The Bear children do not belong to this Agency, but live at The Pas and both parents are very shiftless, the father being more or less of a drunkard and the mother moving from house to house wherever she can obtain shelter. Dr. Yule claimed that both these children were under-nourished due to home conditions and recommended that I have them admitted to Residential School where they would have institutional care.

Would you kindly advise if these applications will now be approved by the Department.

Your December 1949 Quarterly Return has been received and checked and it has been noted that when pupils are in residence for less than the prescribed number of days for the Quarter you fail to show the date the pupils left and later returned to residence.

The Treasury Branch of the Department of Finance and the Auditor-General's office who are entitled to any information deemed necessary insist that dates pupils leave the residence and later return to residence must be shown on the return for all pupils for whom grant is requested for less than the prescribed number of days.

This naturally applies to all pupils whether they are being discharged, absent on account of illness, admission to hospital, truancy, authorized leave of absence or for any other reason.

Please bear this in mind when completing future returns.

Dear Colonel Neary:

Pupils - Anglican Indian School,
Prince Albert, Saskatchewan.

The following extract from a letter, dated 21st September, 1950, from the Principal of All Saints' (Lac la Ronge) School may be of interest to you:

"We have to date three hundred and fourteen children at All Saints'.

Yesterday I got word that there are 17 children to come in from Red Earth. Most of these are girls and so will go to St. Albans which are still short in numbers. It is very difficult to get children for St. Albans when they are limited by sex and grade. Also many parents and agents request that families be kept together if at all possible. A number of new children from Punnichy were grade 5 so only four of the 17 went to St. Albans. There are still new children at Montcalm Lake and Battleford Reserves which could be brought in. If all the children from Red Earth come in St. Albans should have their quota."

The 17 children noted above as from Punnichy are NOT from Gordon's Reserve but from Moscow, Poormans, Day Star and Fishing Lake who were sent to Prince Albert after consultation with you on 13th September, 1950.

The points raised about the difficulty in allocating children to St. Albans' (Onion Lake) by sex and age when Agents and parents wish families to be kept together seem to warrant consideration.

Yours truly,

Henry G. Cook,
Superintendent.

I am enclosing herewith a letter received from the Rev. N. D.
Pilcher, Principal of the S. A. Alban's Indian Res. School, Prince
Albert, Sask. which will be found self-explanatory.

A few minutes ago I received a call from the matron of the school
advising that both girls had left the school this morning without
permission. It is quite evident the staff of this school are not
capable of keeping these girls under control. Nina Bird, age
14 is the daughter of William Bird, No. 89, Wm. Charles Band.
Elsie May Charles, Age 13, is the daughter of Adam Charles,
No. 331 of the Lac La Ronge Band.

I recommend that Elsie May Charles be discharged from the school
immediately. Please advise if you concur in my decision.

Winnipeg, Manitoba.

Re: Application; Admission
Indian Residential Schools

With reference to the above subject. Some time ago I was informed that children had been admitted to All Saints Indian Residential School at Prince Albert, Saskatchewan, from this Agency, without the necessary authority having been received from Ottawa.

Upon writing the Principal, Rev. A.J. Serase (copy of letter attached) I received a reply (copy also attached) enclosing three application for admission forms covering the three unauthorized admissions.

In view of the fact that the children are now at the school and it would not be to the benefit of the children concerned, to move them in the middle of a term, I have signed the application forms. The forms are enclosed and I am leaving it to your decision whether to forward them to Ottawa, or not.

As you are no doubt aware the practice of admitting the children first and applying for authority after, has been rampant at various schools in the past even though it is against Department Regulations.

May I suggest a circular letter be sent to all Principals of Residential Schools pointing out the practice is against Regulations.

J.H. Stanton,
Supt. Indian Agency.
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. of Citizenship & Immigration,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Re: Application; Admission
Indian Residential Schools

Copy of a letter dated February 8th, 1951 received from Superintendent J.H. Staunton of Dauphin which is self-explanatory is being attached hereto. It is noted that the children are already in the school and under the circumstances, it is considered advisable not to have them transferred at this time.

I am in agreement with Superintendent Staunton's suggestion to remind all principals that it is contrary to regulations to accept these children without first submitting an application to the Department for approval.

R. S. Davis,
Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies.

Sir:

I have received through Mr. Leng Turner, Indian Agent, Onion Lake, a request from the Principal of the Onion Lake Anglican Residential School, to be supplied by the Department with 16 milk cows on the ground that the 8 cows which they at present possess have been in use for the past ten years and are not giving a sufficient quantity of milk and further, that the pupilage of the school has doubled.

I cannot understand why the Department should be called upon to furnish so large a number of cows, if indeed any at all. Other schools have been obliged to provide their own milk cows and I do not see any reason why an exception should be made in the case of the Onion Lake School. I shall be glad to receive an expression of opinion from the Department.

Your obedient servant,

W.M. Graham,
Indian Commissioner.

December 2, 1926.

Memorandum:

Dr. Scott,

Mr. Indian Agent Turner has forwarded to Mr. Commissioner Graham a request from the Principal of the Onion Lake C. E. Indian Residential School. It is represented that 15 milch cows are required. It appears that the 8 they have on hand should be slaughtered as they are too old for milking purposes.

Mr. Commissioner Graham recommends that none be supplied. But we have helped nearly all the other Indian residential schools in the Prairies in the matter of stock. I wish to suggest that we supply five (5) head, on condition that the school management secure an equal number.

Supt. of Indian Education.

The Inspector points out that they have 30 head of cattle and that the stable only contains 21 stalls. The gentlemen at the head of the Indian Department are well aware of the fact that one of the most successful factors in bringing about the civilization of the Indians is the school well conducted and well attended. With this fact in view, many efforts have been made by those in charge of the Indian affairs in order to secure for the children the benefit of a good education. Day schools have been established throughout the reserves to aid the purpose, a peak around every corner, and many have been put in by those who are more or less interested in the solution of the great problem of the civilization of the Indians. But unfortunately difficulties unforeseen have proved the day schools to be a dismal failure.

To the honor, let it be said, of those gentlemen who preside at the management of Indian affairs, a new plan which seems to justify the most sanguine hopes of the educated parties has been devised and already put in execution. Boarding schools entrusted to the intelligent and generous care of those well qualified for the purpose have taken the place of day schools, and I may say, so far as I am able to judge, the boarding schools do concern, having my impression in what I have seen and on the unprejudiced reports, boarding schools have been a success so far. Through the new system difficulties which hitherto have baffled the intelligence of the Indian Department and teachers alike have been overcome. The natural aptitude of the Indians (speaking of Ojibwa reserve) for the education of their children has been awakened to a certain extent, and a strong desire of having their children brought up under the civilized care of the sisters has been raised, so much that at the present time the Red Sisters are confronted with the task necessity of requiring a great number of children as boarders on account of their lack of resources, and consequently we are unable to favor the development of this new spirit amongst the Indians and thereby depriving many of the benefits of a good education.

One who is not fully cognizant with the real facts might make this observation, namely: That the children...
The children who cannot be taken as boarders may attend day-school and thereby receive a certain education.

To this, allow me to say further the same reasons which have caused the day-schools to be a failure in some cases. Moreover, experience compels me to state that the idea of having boarding schools attended by dayschool children is pretty near next to the impossible. Dayschool children, most of whom poorly clad and poorly fed, are not able to sustain the difference existing between them and those of the boarding school better clad and carpeted, and the perception of their inferiority causes them to be more than ever against their attending the school. While they would get happy to attend the school as boarders, they show the idea of attending the school as dayschool children. Therefore, unless the Indians take these children under their personal expense, they would remain ignorant, that is, savage as ever.

But, as I say in the beginning of my letter, the Board dealers are utterly incapable to take care of these children and treat them as boarders, unless the Indian Department extending the measure of its liberality, grant their petition and allow them to take forty instead of twenty.

We occupy the number 47, because we are obliged to do so; but we could get more than that if we were in a position to do so.

I am sincerely convinced that you are also well aware of our strong desire to secure the education of the Indians' children and that we are ready to expend upon no personal sacrifice in time and money to a great extent, but presently it is impossible for the Board Dealers to do more unless the government come to their assistance.

You are also well aware of the position of Orono Lake, the difficulties of communication, the cost of transport &c., and for all the reasons above mentioned, and encouraged by our Agent Mr.
Mr. Mann whose untiring efforts for the promotion of the temporal welfare of the Indians cannot be too much appreciated. I take the liberty in behalf of the Red Sisters to ask a favorable answer to their petition, assuring you before hand of any heartfelt gratitude.

I have asked for a grant of $1,200.00 to help covering the expenses of building the Boarding School at the Blood Reserve, and for another sum of $1,200.00 to help also covering the expenses of the building for a Boarding school at the Blackfoot Reserve.

You would have cost a great deal without making even then a decent building. By completing the whole building, in its main component parts at least, I am sure that we have made a very substantial saving, for the Department.
We have gone into large expenses, besides over the Government grant, that we have paid already; but there still about $1200.00 due on each building for lumber taken at Peter McLennan MacLeod, for the Blood School, & at the Canclaire Co., Calgary, for the Blackfoot Crossing School, & these companies, of course, are anxious to be paid, as soon as possible, for the material supplied.

I hope that your Department will be willing to pay this debt of $1200.00 on each of these buildings, & in such case we would put no application for the purpose of securing back the other sums paid by us.

Hon. Sir:

I beg to draw your attention to the arduous problem we are confronted with in the successful management of our Boarding School namely:

The ever increasing cost of living, and as a result; the inefficiency of the actual per Capita school grant as an adequate means to give our children committed to our care, the rational and healthy comfort they are entitled to.

I will learn you nothing when I make you aware of the fact that the high cost of living is becoming a very serious proposition for such an institution as ours.

A return to the pre-war state of things is not to be dreamed of, as prices for everything are still soaring and the top has not been reached yet.

Therefore I feel it my duty bound to apprise you of the strenuous difficulties we are against in carrying out the Department's regulations concerning the boarding and the clothing of the children under our care.

Hitherto it has been a matter of great concern to us, to supply our children with what was considered the best in matter of food and clothing, as directed by the Dept., so much so, that both the local authority and the Indians were wont to make us known their entire satisfaction with the manner we were taking care of our wards.

But under the awful stress we have to carry on the work, I feel bound to inform you that henceforth, it would be impossible to keep up to our standard, unless...
an increase in the per capita grant is allotted to us by
the Department, substantial enough to enable us to run
our school without incurring an annual deficit.

For a long time we have been contemplating the idea of
improving the buildings so that our Boarding School
might share in the maximum grant given out to certain us
to date schools under the supervision of the Department.

But unfortunately, the high cost for everything pertaining
to the good maintenance of our school, our being at
a great distance from the nearest station, the scarcity
of material in our surroundings and our financial string-
ency owing to an inadequate per capita grant, makes it
imperative for us to postpone the intended improvements
till the situation comes back to its normal if it ever
comes.

However, I may say, although, we have not all the up to
date conveniences and improvements existing in some other
institutions better favored than ours, our school, never-
theless, offers our children all the necessary requisites required for their welfare.

Good spacious rooms, well heated and well lighted and
a system of ventilation which affords fresh and pure air
whenever necessary, so much so, that in the long winter we
are just coming through, we had no sickness to report, and
right now our children are the very picture of health.

Of course it would be a matter of great satisfaction
to us, were we in a position to go through with the improve-

the present circumstances, unless the Department sees its

MEMORANDUM

In an effort to determine the amount of accommodation which should be provided in the new Onion Lake R. C. Indian Residential School, I have studied the census returns for the reserves which can be considered in this institution's regular recruiting district. There are a total of approximately 154 Roman Catholic children of school age in the area in question. 126 of these children are on the Onion Lake, Keeheesin, Frog Lake and Iseland Lake reserves. Approximately 20 percent of these would be found physically unfit for residential school life. I, therefore, conclude that 100 children can be secured from these 4 reserves if a campaign is carried on with success. I might point out that over 50 of the 60 children at present enrolled in the school come from these reserves.

There is another group of Indians that must be considered in connection with the Onion Lake R. C. Dear Sir:

For causes unknown to me, "The Return Form for the Principal's Fiscal Year Report has reached me only yesterday because I called for my mail at Lloydminster P.O.

Unfortunately I was not able to send it to you before today.

As you will see, the Principal's Salary, Sisters' Salaries and the Engineer who is a member of our religious Order have not been paid in full or even half. This is due to the fact that I had to renew many things as House Equipment, Repairs. The building being built for nearly 9 years requires many repairs and also all the material supplied by the Indian Dept. when the school opened has been worn out. Therefore a great portion of the allowance goes in that direction.

This year the farm brought in $1232.30 and beside 6535 lbs of beef and 1450 lbs of pork was supplied by the farm as Food supplies for the school. By increasing and improving the farm I expect to be able to meet all my obligations.

Transportation is another heavy item being so far away from town or Railway.

The pasture on the school ground is absolutely ruined and needs to be ploughed entirely and is not large enough for our live stock. Every year I experience trouble with the Indians and also I loose some heads. Lately I asked with our local Indian Agent the Indians to let me have a little pasture on the Reserve and they refused. Perhaps if the Indian Dept. takes up this question with the Indians we will have a better success. Dr. J.T. Hill Indian Agent was supposed to report this matter to the Dept.

I am very sorry to see that you are on the impression that I deal with your Dept without passing through the Local Indian Agency Office as per stated in your April 28th --115-2-114

May I state that before writing to the Dept. I always discuss every subject with the Indian Agent and upon his suggestion I then write to the Dept. I will be pleased always to act according to the Dept. Regulations as it is my greater desire to do everything right and honestly.

Hoping Dear Mr. MacKenzie, that this letter will be well received and the details contained useful to the Dept.

yours truly

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

Dear Sir:

We have been very disappointed by your letter of the 19th Oct. Being convinced that we were authorized to take thirty boarders, not only did we admit such a number, but so as to more fully meet the wishes of the Department, and remedy to a want felt by all those who are interested, we moreover have admitted ten boarders for whom we receive no grant.

Our object was to give to the larger number of our Indian children in the same degree the benefit of an unbroken course of instruction.

You are aware that children attending the Day School and returning to their homes in the evening, do not, or nearly so, profit by the School, for the reason that the children do not attend the greatest part of the year owing to their fickleness and the carelessness of parents. To remedy this inconvenience, we have taken upon ourselves to admit ten children above the number allowed, relying upon the fact that we were authorized to take thirty boarders.

You can see how we are fixed. We receive the grant for only 25, and have 15 more which we

A. Forget Esqr,
Regina.
we receive no grant. We do not forget that we receive rations for the latter and $1.00. ahead a month, but this is as nothing compared to the expenses for their clothing, and food, especially when we are obliged to erect an expensive and comfortable building for these children. If we had resources upon which we could rely, but such is not the case. We must absolutely rely on the Department's grant and in a locality remote from large centres where we must pay high rates for everything in the way of food or clothing for the children. You can see the trouble we are in.

I leave it to your spirit of justice to see the means to remedy this awkward situation which has been brought upon us by some kind of a misapprehension. However I beg the Department to consider our request to have a larger amount of children as earners of the grant. Considering the number of children of school age, the distance between here and large towns where everything costs less, we ask anew an increase of the grant for ten children above the 25 we are already allowed as boarders. It must not be forgotten that 50 children of school age could be had here. We have built a house which can offer comfort and accommodation for such a number. I request you, dear Sir, to strongly urge the justice of this demand upon
upon the Department of which you are one of the more appreciated Officers.

We are well disposed to do everything in our power to keep the Department in reaching the goal it looks for in the matter of the education of the Indian children; we appreciate their true values the sacrifices made by the Government in order to solve the problem of the education and civilization of the Indians, and I take this opportunity to thank him, whoever he is, for the grant which has been allowed us for the 25 boarders of our school; but considering the urgency of giving to a large number of those children who are of school age, the benefit of a solid training, and also that our financial resources are insufficient to do more than we are doing at present, we beg the Department to do justice to our demand.

Hoping that our request will be taken into favourable consideration,

I etc,

(signed) J. A. Therien Ft. O. M. I.
Onion Lake,
Dec. 3rd 1895.

Dear Sir:

In November 1894, the School house having been burnt down here, we began the erection of a boarding School. To meet the wants which were felt and the desire of the Department, we resolved upon building a spacious house wherein all the necessary comfort could be found for the children, who might be taken as boarders. This house, 35' by 45' three stories, begun in November 1894 was terminated in November 1895. Today there are forty children residing in the same. The ground floor divided in two rooms is intended for the class room, and for the girls workroom; the 2nd story is also divided in two, one for the boys dormitory, the other for the girls; the top story is not yet finished.

For this building, 50,000 feet of lumber have been used, the Department has contributed 12,000 as against the school house which had been burnt down, so that we have provided 38,143 feet to erect this building. I enclose the details of the expenses in connection with it, amounting to $2165.88.

We are thankful to the Department

A. E. Forget Esqr,
Regina.
for the 12,000 feet of lumber we have received, but considering that this house is a School for the Indian children only, we beg to take leave to ask the Department to be kind enough to help us to pay the expenses that we were obliged to go to erect it.

We see that the Department goes to a large output for the education of Indian children, and we cannot but praise it for the same; at the same time we beg the Department to consider that it is impossible for us to answer to its desire in giving to the children all the necessary comfort and adequate room if we are obliged to clothe, feed and shelter them out of the grant received from the Government.

We therefore pray the Government to aid us in defraying the expenses we have gone to in this building. We beg that the number of the children we keep as boarders, without the grant usually allowed them as such, be considered.

We beg the Department also to consider that, considering the promise received of a grant for 30 pupils when ultimately the grant was only for 25, we have been induced to take a larger number of pupils. This disappointment has put us to great financial embarrassment, specially for having to pay the cost of house, expensive, it is true, but at the same time necessary and occupied exclusively by Indian children.

I am etc.

(sd) J. A. Therien Pt. O. M. I.

THE SECRETARY,

I beg to submit herewith an application from the Principal of the Roman Catholic Boarding School at Onion Lake for a grant to build an addition to that school.

The Principal does not mention the amount required, but the Commissioner states that in a private conversation with the Coadjutor Bishop of St. Albert he learned that $1500 would cover the expenditure, and he recommends that the Department grant aid to the extent of $750.

In view of the Minister's decision not to make any grants at present for new buildings for industrial or boarding schools, I do not suppose anything will be done in this case, particularly in consideration of the fact that the Onion Lake Boarding School building belongs to the Roman Catholic Church, and it has been the practice of the Department to decline to make grants to buildings not owned by it.

H.C. Ross.

Sir:

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 16th instant, No. 122/69, enclosing an application from the Principal of the Roman Catholic boarding school at Onion Lake for a grant to erect an addition to the school building.

In connection with this request you state that in a private conversation with the Conductor Bishop of St. Albert you have learned that $1500 would be the probable cost of the addition, and you recommend that the Department contribute $750.

In reply I may say that in view of the Minister's decision not to make grants at present for new buildings for industrial or boarding schools, and particularly in consideration of the fact that the Opeongo Anishnag boarding school building is not the property of the Department, nothing can be done this year in the direction above indicated.

OTTAWA, 27th April, 1900

The Secretary:

Re: Application for a grant to assist in enlarging the Roman Catholic boarding school at Onion Lake.

Provision is made for fifty pupils at this school at the usual per capita grant of $72 per annum and it has its full quota of children.

Mr Inspector Chisholm in his report on this school, dated the 22nd December last, states that with the present attendance the school stands in need of a second class-room, a convenient and suitable kitchen, at least one additional recreation room and a larger dining-room and boys' dormitory, and attached to his report is a plan and estimate for the erection of an addition to the school building, which was prepared by the Principal and approved by him. The estimate comes to $3357.30 but the item for wages could, the Inspector states, be much reduced by utilizing the labor of the senior boys under the instruction of a competent and skilled carpenter. The Indian Commissioner, in a marginal note, says that the Inspector has exceeded his duty in approving of the estimate and plan, and that such provision has been made in the estimates as was considered reasonable. The Department informed the Commissioner that it concurred.
concurred in his opinion, as expressed in the note above referred to and that the Inspector should be so informed, as such action on his part was likely to compromise the Department.

A new building was completed for this school about three years ago, towards which the Department contributed $129 about $2000.00 and it was supposed to furnish accommodation for the same number of pupils as are now provided for.

If the Department contributes anything towards the enlargement of the buildings a grant for an increased number of pupils is sure to be asked for.

The Church of England has a boarding school on this reserve with provision for only 15 pupils and there has always been considerable jealousy between the two schools, and my experience is that when a concession is made to a boarding school a similar one has to be made to its neighbor of a different denomination.

I may add that the Department's contribution covered almost the total cost of the Roman Catholic school building. The accompanying photographs will give you a good idea of the each of these school buildings.

Father Comire's letter addressed to Mr Davis M.P., is returned herewith.

SIR:

Your reply to Mr. Turner's letter and mine submitting to the Department the expenses in connection with the excavation of a cellar to our Boarding School, and asking the help of the same to cover the said expenses, has been transmitted to me.

In your answer you lay stress on the fact that the Department were not referred to before going into such outlay, and that the school being the church's property the expenses should be met by the church.

True we did not previously communicate with the Department, before undertaking the work, for reasons that we had no intention to go into such expenses.

At the outset we thought a little repair would do for this year and we had made up our mind to meet the expenses ourselves, with the intention to ask an appropriation from the Department next year in case we had to make a new foundation.

But as we proceeded with the work we soon found out that it was urgent to tackle the whole work right now, that it was not safe to delay any longer, the foundation giving away everywhere, the beams and the whole under structure being utterly rotten and beyond repairing.

After laying the case before Mr. Turner we decided to go on at once with the work we had in mind to postpone till next year, after having referred the matter to the Department.

Thus what we thought could be attended to next year, had to be carried through right away.

We were taken unaware and could not ascertain before beginning the work the necessity of pushing it through to a finish.

To wait and communicate with the Department was out of the question as we had to hurry the work before the reopening of the school in August.

We had no other alternative than to go on and to communicate with the Department once the work would be done, although we had the approval of our Agent Mr. Turner as to the urgency of going in such outlay.

As to the fact that our school is the church's property, I would simply say, that considering that the annual grant allotted for the maintenance of the school is barely sufficient, it would seem that the Indians through the Department, could help covering such expenses.

I beg also to draw your attention to the fact that being far away from any center, the nearest town being Lloydminster 40 miles, we had to rely on the only man staying here to do the work.

Under the circumstances it was impossible to meet the requirements of the Purchasing Commission of Canada.

I have the honour to enclose herewith a letter received from Rev. J.A. Therien, principal of the Onion Lake R.C. Boarding School, in which he asks me to make a recommendation to the Department for an appropriation of about $200.00 for the purpose of building a new chimney at the school.

A new and larger chimney is absolutely necessary at this school. One of the old chimneys, a small one, only 8" square inside, which rested on a bracket in the kitchen and which was fed by six stoves, caught fire a few weeks ago and for a short time it was feared that the whole building would take fire; as it was some of the interior woodwork was badly scorched.

Father Therien and I have gone into this matter with Mr. G.T. Hunter, builder, of Onion Lake, who recommended Father Therien to build a chimney with an inside measurement of 17"x21¾" and 40' high, and also to have the small one built up from the basement, and the bracket in the kitchen done away with.

The large chimney would relieve the present congestion in the small chimneys, of which there are five in the main building and would add greatly to the safety of the buildings.

I do not think the cost will be quite as much as Father Therien has asked for. The following is my estimate:

Mr. Scott:

A request has been received from the Principal of the Onion Lake R.C. Boarding School, forwarded through the office of the Indian Agent, for a grant of $200 for the purpose of building a new chimney at the school. It is stated that this large chimney would relieve the present congestion in the small chimneys of which there are five in the main building, and would greatly add to the safety of the buildings. I would point out that this school is the property of the Church authorities.

Last year we paid accounts to the amount of $769.15 for material and labour in putting in a new foundation and digging a large cellar under the school. This work was carried out by the Principal without referring the matter to the Department, and he subsequently asked that payment be made, which was done on your authority.

I shall be pleased to have your recommendation as to whether authority should be granted for the expenditure of $200 for the purpose of building a new chimney.

Sir:

Desiring to comply with the wishes of the Indian Department and to co-operate with it in its endeavour to promote the interest of education among the Indians, I take the liberty to draw your attention to the fact that here in this Union Lake Agency, notwithstanding the efforts of both the Agent and missionaries, the problem of educating the Indian children is still in abeyance.

Due to the lack of accommodation in our boarding school many children are therefrom deprived of the benefit of adequate education. And we, the Roman Catholic missionaries feel it all the more, that most of the Indians under the management of this agency belong to our Church. Here at Union Lake out of forty or forty-five Indian families, thirty-six belong to our church.

Frog Lake, out of twenty-five, more or less, fifteen are Roman Catholics at Kiyewin, or Long Lake, every family, twenty-five more or less, belongs to our Church, the same for Cold Lake Reserve.

Such so, that the Boarding School under the management of the Church in England, must get its pupils from the other surrounding agencies, Le Lacle or Thunderchild. So that most of the problem rest on ourselves and we are well aware that we cannot cope with it under the present circumstances.

Pre: Only we have fifty-five children in our boarding school and owing to lack of room, we cannot take more, so that there are many children who should be in the school and who are not.

True, there are two day schools in operation in this agency, at Long Lake and Cold Lake. But, you are well aware, that notwithstanding the efforts made to have them effectives, it is utterly impossible owing to the inability of the parents to send their children regularly to school. The consequences are that many children do not receive the proper education such as the department and the missionaries alike, would like to give them.

Under the circumstances I think that steps should be taken to remedy the situation, the only way, is to have a larger school. Up to now, the Indians were satisfied with the way the education was given to their children, but for a certain time they show a great deal more of interest in the education of their children and desire to put their children in the boarding school when to our sorrow we have to refuse the admission of the children from lack of room.

As an example of this new tendency, I may say that hitherto it was almost impossible to get children from Long Lake Reserve, and now we have twenty-one who belong to that reserve; and more could be taken had we the room to accommodate them. So, according to the missionaries and those who are interested in the education of the Indian, a larger school should be built, and built as soon as possible.

A building that could accommodate one hundred children, the number of children belonging to the reserve under the management of this agency warrants this number. Had we the place right now, we could get easily this number.

It is out of question to put an addition to our old building. This should be discarded altogether and a new one built in an up-to-date fashion, so that we may have all the accommodations required by the Department.

I visited this school on the 9th inst. The children had just returned from their holidays a few days previously. I found the building scrupulously clean throughout. This building has been reported on before; it has surely fulfilled its purpose and a new school is badly required. I may say that it has not been considered wise to incur any great expenditure in repairing this building in view of the prospects of a new school. However, as I have already reported to you, some repairs will have to be made to the floors in order to render them safe.

There is no farming carried on in connection with this school. They have a large garden which provides an ample supply of vegetables for their use. They keep ten milch cows, seven of which were giving milk at the time. The Sister in charge informed me that they were poor milkers and they should have at least four more cows to provide for their requirements. They have a nice flock of poultry and they also raise pigs.

When in the sewing room the Sister pointed out that the Sewing Machine for tailoring work was over thirty years old and was pretty well worn out. I was asked to place before the Department their request for a new machine. There are 57 pupils in attendance at this school at the present time.

Dear Sir,

I am sending you as requested in your letter one blue print copy of a sketch plan for our school, and I may say, that if the plan is entirely carried out, the building will be a credit to the Department and to the architect.

As to the interior of the building, very few suggestions are needed beside those previously made and which have been acted upon in the drawing of the sketch which at the present time is returning to you. However, you will find attached to this sheet a list containing old suggestions and some new ones.

I beg to submit that on the Ground and first floor, doors be put up at both ends of the corridors at the place I have marked. I consider this suggestion very important as its adoption will, in a great measure, do away with many inconveniences complained against in such institutions as ours. It will go a long way in dulling the noise which some time is almost unbearable and establish a sane and very desirable privacy between the visitors, the staffs and the children. Permit me, Sir, to lay stress on that point and draw your attention to it.

Furthermore I beg to call your attention to the fact that in the Boys' Girls Dormitories there is no provisions for Toilet and guardian's rooms. We consider that these accommodations are as much needed there as they are for the other dormitories provided with such utilities. The boys and the girls, sleeping there, will need as much watching, if not more, than those occupying the second floor dormitories. So for the sake of morality and greater efficiency, allow me, dear Sir, to insist on that point.

In order to give the Boy's dormitory on the first floor its full capacity, I take the liberty to suggest that the bed room adjacent to the dormitory be converted into a toilet room. As for the girl's, I really do not see how it could be done as there is no space around vacant.

You will remark that the corridor on the first floor gives a free and easy access to the two dormitories, so that it would be easy for the boys and the girls to arrange secret meetings. This corridor should be shut up by doors to preclude such eventualities.

A Sun room is very desirable in such institutions, and I expect to get one. But where to locate it? Of course it ought to face the south and
and as our building will be facing the south, how will it do to build two sun rooms one each side of the front balcony, provide, of course these two rooms do not in any way disparage the outlook of the building. I leave to your artistic sense the solution of this problem.

I have shown this plan to my Superior and to the Indian Agent, and both of them are greatly elogious in their appreciations. But both of them also concur with me in the idea that it is too bad that the building be not a little larger, that is: instead of being 140 feet long, it is met 155. Then it will be nearer as possible to perfection. As it is now it will be almost impossible to accommodate more than 85 or 90 children in the dormitories. However I suppose you have your instructions and have to carry them out. Any way, if that last suggestion could be acted upon the Department would have built a school that could be considered as a model in that line.

Your's truly,

Dec. 30th. 1926.

The Honorable D. Scott,
Superintendent of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Sir:

In the last interview I had the honor to have with you in company of Father Guy, you gave me to understand that the Department intends to build a Residential school at Onion lake in the course of the next summer.

Assuming that such would be the case, I take the liberty to humbly submit to your consideration the advisability of erecting a school large enough to accommodate 120 children or more. I think that I am not asking too much and I believe that the following facts warrant my demand.

The Onion lake reserve is in the center of a large district extending seventy miles to the west and eighty miles to the east. In that district there are many Indian Reserves such as Long lake, Frog lake, and Onion lake in the west and the Little and Big Island lakes, Thunder Child, Meadow lake, Water Hen, Jack Fish lake, Sweet Grass, Roundmaker, Little Pine and Eagle Hills in the east.

In these Reserves there are only three Residential schools. Two of these schools are under the management of the Catholic church, one at Delmas and the other at Onion lake, the other being under the care of the Church of England. It is therefore obvious that unless the buildings be of a fairly large size they would not meet the requirements of the situation.

In these Reserves a very large percentage of the Indians belong to the Catholic Church and we the missionaries who attend to their spiritual welfare are utterly satisfied that unless our two schools can accommodate each 120 children or more, a certain number each year would be deprived of the benefits derived from the Residential schools.

I may state also that the Indian agent, Mr. Turner and Doctor Hill share my contention in this matter. It is imperative that the matter be given immediate at-
Attention as the plan such as it is, renders any addition to the building in the future impossible.

Furthermore I would say that the building of a Residential school at Cold lake would in any way change the situation as the Cree will not send their children in a school where the majority of the children is Chipewyan. Our experience bears me out in this contention.

Hoping that my request will receive a favorable answer,

I am, Honorable Sir,

Your's faithfully,

(Signed) Principal

January 10, 1927.

In an effort to determine the amount of accommodation which should be provided in the new Onion Lake R. C. Indian Residential School, I have studied the census returns for the reserves which can be considered in this institution's regular recruiting district. There are a total of approximately 184 Roman Catholic children of school age in the area in question. 126 of these children are on the Onion Lake, Kesewewin, Frog Lake and Island Lake Reserves. Approximately 20 percent of these would be found physically unfit for residential school life. I therefore conclude that 100 children can be educated from these reserves if a campaign is carried on with success. I might point out that over 50 of the 60 children at present enrolled in the school come from these reserves.

There is another group of Indians that must be considered in connection with the Onion Lake R. C. Indian School, - the Chipewyans, Cold Lake, etc., with a Roman Catholic school population of 37 - 30 of whom would likely be fit. The school, however, has not been popular with the Chipewyans, as there are but 2 enrolled at present, yet there is a potential pupilage of about 25.

There are 20 Catholic children of school age belonging to the Meadow Lake Band, and the Onion Lake School is closest for them, but I find that they are all enrolled at Thunderchild.

I consider that a pupilage of not more than 110 should be allowed. Mr. Orr states that the plans can be altered slightly to care for this number and that the estimate already prepared will not need any change.

Onion Lake, April 20th, 1937

To the Honorable Duncan Scott,
Deputy Sup. General,
Ottawa.

I beg to acknowledge receipt of our proposed school's plan and specifications. Truly if the specifications are carried out to the letter the building will give entire satisfaction to all concerned. But will they be carried out? Undoubtedly it is the intention of the Department that the contractor complies with the specifications laid down. But you are well aware that they are not all reliable. Some are honest, some are not. Who will get the contract? Nobody knows yet. But who-ever gets it, I hope he will be reliable.

It is to be most desirable against any contract that the Dept. will have a good honest and experienced inspector to supervise the work at the very outset. I was told by Father Guy that His Lordship Bishop Charlebois and Father Buellet were both satisfied with their inspectors. And that either one or the other would give us entire satisfaction. We hope that the Dept. will see to it and appoint one of them as it is imperative that we should be protected.

It is a well known fact that green lumber has been used in the building of the School in the Church of England century, I am sure, to the specifications laid to the prejudice of the school. And I am well aware that the same man who sold green lumber to the contractor expects to do the same this year with our school. The agent or the inspector should I think be instructed by the Dept. to not allow any thing of the kind.

This winter and right now, the principal of the church of England's school has much trouble with the drainage system as the pipes are frozen and cannot locate the places that they have to carry water in barrels. The trenches as far I was told are only six or seven feet deep. Now in this country where there is not much snow the ground is liable to freeze eight or nine feet deep, so that the trenches ought to be not less than ten feet deep. I think that in Edmonton it is about the average depth of the trenches in the streets, if not more. I have not seen the specifications about the drainage but I hope that this fact is not overlooked. I must submit that the situation is serious. It is that point that it is of a paramount importance. Imagine the predicament we should be in were the pipes getting frozen specially in a place like ours where experienced men are scarce and hard to get.

I understand that Mr. Graham has wired the Dept. about the location of our school. It is a good place for cultivation and beside a good spring which well utilized would give a good supply of water. But I submit that an expert man ought to be charged with the boring of the spring so that all the water it can give shall be secured.

I thought dear Sir, that these informations might be of any interest to you and might help making a first class work of this building.

Your very truly,

[Signature]

Dear Sir,

I presume that it is the intention of the Department to build a stable and poultry house for our new school right this summer as a matter of great necessity. Where the school is located there is no building of any kind that could be used for the purpose. In fact there is none whatever and it is imperative that the stable be built before we move in the new school. Very likely the work will be done and through in the middle of next winter and then if we have to move as we shall have to imagine the predicament we shall be in, having no building of any kind to stable our cattle and horses. As I said before it is of the utmost necessity that the stable and poultry house be built this summer so that next winter we shall have to move then we shall have the building to stable our stock.

Re.- Building for the Principal.

I have been told that the Department is willing to build a house for the principal only for the asking. I for one exceedingly desire of having a home for myself and my assistant. The prospect of having to live in the school with the children is to say the least, exceedingly contrary to my liking and inclination. And I think that only for the sake of safeguarding his influence over the children it is greatly desirable that the principal should live apart of the school in his own house. And since the Department is not contrary to the idea, I do ask the same to build a house for the Principal right this summer.

The building will be about the same as was built for Mr. Ellis, only a little larger as we intend to have Lay-Brothers to run our farm and machineries and naturally the principal's house will be theirs also, therefore necessitating a larger building. If the Hon. Deputy Supt. desires it I would be glad to forward him a sketch of the building I would like to get.

I greatly wish that the house be built this summer in the same time as the school so that it would be easy then to arrange for the water system while the working men would be there on the spot working at the school.

Dear Sir, I would be exceedingly pleased were the Dept. in a position to gratify my demand which by the way is endorsed entirely by my Provincial, Father Boys, and you would do me a great favor which I will not easily forget were you using your influence in my behalf.

Thanking you for the anticipated favor, I remain, Your's truly,

STANLEY BROCK LIMITED.
Yesterday the inspector, Mr. Hamilton and myself in looking over the plan for our new residential school agreed that some minor alterations were advisable, namely:

1. One outdoor for the boys and one for the girls recreation rooms. You will kindly notice that the children have access to their respective recreation room by passing through a corridor therefore increasing the burden of watching them when they go out and come in. The guardian would have to be in the corridor most of the time to watch them. An outdoor will do away with that inconvenience.

2. There is no provision for a sitting room for the Indians when they come to see the principal on private business. They have to stay in the corridor or get in his office five or ten at a time. I would suggest that the principal's office be made a sitting room for the Indians and the present bed room for the principal be made his office and the next bed room be his own bed room. This alteration would be made by simply putting a door in the wall separating the principal's bed room and the next bed room.

3. For the sake of privacy for the visitors, the principal and his assistant and also to dull the noise and escape the dust that comes from the class room and recreation room down below I strongly recommend that the corridor on the ground floor be closed at both ends by putting doors. I have heard many principal emphasizing the necessity of it and I strongly recommend it.

4. I would suggest also to extend the verandah in order to give more room.

5. To close the corridor leading to the girls dormitory by putting a door. Very important to prevent any undue access to the dormitory.

6. A concrete reservoir for rain water.

7. A 20 H.P. Engine at least.

Total: 6 doors 2 outside doors and 4 inside doors.
Extension of verandah
Reservoir for rain water
20 h.p. engine

These are the extras I beg to strongly recommend hoping that you would be kind enough to grant my demand entirely endorsed by the Inspector, Mr. Hamilton. Expecting a favorable answer,

Dear Sir,

In answer to your letter of Aug 4th re Water Supply System and Sewage Disposal Plant for the R C Indian School being erected here.

Referring to the Water System I do not think that the system as installed in the Church of England here could be improved on as they tell me it is giving good satisfaction. You mentioned in your letter about an elevated water tank being suggested, but in my opinion it would not be satisfactory.

Regarding the Disposal Plant, I would suggest the same design as the system installed at the Church of England School here. The lay of the land here is about the same as the other but the piping from the disposal tank would not be quite so far in this one, and I should judge that the tank might be made a little larger. I have written to the Provincial Department of Health for pamphlets explaining the requirements for a school of this size when I could forward you a sketch.

The water system as installed at the C of E School requires a well at the spring and a pump house with a gasoline engine and a pump, with a pipe line about 650 ft long of 2½" pipe to storage tank near machinery room and also connected to two pneumatic pressure tanks about 4' x 12' with an automatic electric pump also a booster pump to supply air to tanks when required.

If the above system is to be installed, the pressure tanks should be put in at once if they are to be put under the machinery room floor which would have to be excavated to receive them as per my letter of July 4th. The contractor will be raising the walls of that part of the building about the end of next week, and if the excavating is to be done it will have to be done before the walls are erected, so I would ask you to wire me if you want them there.

Dear Sir,

In my previous letter to you I laid stress upon the urgency of having our stable built up this year. Today I am sending a telegram to draw again your attention to this matter. I hope that the Department will see to it that our demand will be granted and that instruction will be given at once to go ahead with the building of the barn.

It will be almost impossible to move this winter in our new school if we have no barn to stable our stock, as there is no building of any kind around that could be used for that purpose. It is of the utmost importance that the building be put up this year while the building of our school is going on.

I take also the liberty to ask the department to build a house for our farmer who is a married man with a family. We shall need the service of that man as soon as we take possession of the school and a building should be provided for him and his family right this summer. Will you kindly take this matter into serious consideration and give instruction to that effect. The present contractor could do the work of the barn and the farmer's house in the same time he is building the school.

I beg to insist upon the urgency of these matters, and I hope that my suggestions will be acted upon as a failure to do so will put us in a very awkward situation.

With my best regard and wishes for your welfare,

I am, Your's truly,

Dear Sirs,

As Inspector of Construction at the new R C Indian Residential School being erected here I wish to submit to you the following Report on the progress made at the building since I arrived at the Site.

I arrived at the site June 24th and found the Contractor at work at the excavating and building the temporary buildings for offices and storehouses and quarters for the men employed.

The work is progressing very slowly, being partly due to wet weather, delays on material and shortage of labor. The cement work for the walls of main building and footings for columns and partitions are in place. The outside studding is also in place for basement and ground floor and sheeted with shiplap up to the ground floor joists.

They are pouring concrete for walls of rear building under chapel, and they should have them completed this week if not held up for gravel which has been the cause of considerable of the delay in the past.

Practically all the dimension lumber, shiplap, com boards flooring, siding and v joints are at the site. The flooring and siding though both is not according to the specifications, the flooring is a good grade but is 3/4" face that it calls for and wider than 2 1/2" face and on taking the matter up with the contractor he sent after the shippers and they said that it was a mistake in their office billing out the order, the siding is not up to the grade called for and I have refused to accept it unless it is culled out and the inferior material taken away from the job, the dimensions and shiplap is a good quality and the cement work is up to the standard.

Regarding the flooring referred to above I would be pleased to have you send me some that will be acceptable as good a grade as can be procured and it being dried here a distance of over 30 miles it puts the contractors in a bad box for he could not sell it around here in ten years there is so much of it.

I would be pleased hear from you as to the date the contract is supposed to be completed as they do not seem to be trying to push the job the way I think they should.

There are none of the subcontractors arrived at the job yet, but they expect the plumbing and heating men this week. The steel columns have all arrived at the site and the ones for the basement and ground floor are in place.

The above report is respectfully submitted for your consideration. I am

Your obedient servant

Dear Sirs,

As Inspector of Construction at the R C Indian Residential School being erected here wish to report as follows.

The work is progressing very slowly here at the present time, and has been the same since the excavation was completed, at the present time the outside structure of the main building is about closed in, the end portions of which are ready for the felt & gravel roof, and the centre part is being prepared and should be ready for roofing by the end of the week.

The rear wing of the building which includes the Chapel is being prepared to receive the ground floor joists, the rear wall of this wing has been held up for quite a while owing to the delay of the heating contractor in not having the boilers delivered and placed in position, the boilers have not arrived yet but one of them they expect will be at the job to-day and the other one is being unloaded from the car at Lloydminster, and without any mishap both should be in place this week, the plumbers have not arrived at the job yet but are expected to arrive today.

There has been considerable wind and rain in this district which has delayed the work somewhat, but when the building is closed in there should be no more delay in that way, there seems to be a shortage of carpenters in this district at the present time, the window frames are being put in place so that the building can be closed in.

I would recommend that the water system and sewage disposal plant be decided on as soon as possible so that the work may be put under way as the weather in this district cannot be depended on for outside work.

Dear Sir:

Referring to your letter of the 13th July, to Reverend Father Thériaux, my predecessor, I respectfully beg to discuss over again with you the question of the verandah to be built on our new school.

The Reverend Sisters are sorely disappointed at your refusal to have the side verandah extended to at least 40 ft. long x 8 full feet wide. This verandah is for them practically the only place where they can have together a little bit of recreation and fresh air. There will be 14 or 15 Sisters in the new school; how can you expect them to enjoy their verandah when they will be so crowded inside that 20 ft. x 7 ft. bit of a space? The size of the verandah as shown on the plan is at least half too small to answer its real purpose.

Therefore, in the name of our devoted Sisters, I respectfully beg that you reconsider your decision, and that you issue orders immediately to have this change made.

Floors in the Basement.

Another matter, which we wish to ask you to reconsider, is the floors in the Basement.

Most of the Principals of our new Residential Schools, in the West, are dissatisfied with the cement floors. I am aware that in some of these schools, they had to do away with said floors. The objection is that these floors are about impossible to keep clean, free from dust, unsanitary, etc. We fail to understand why your Architect is so persistent in having that kind of floors put in our schools. In some of our own private Institutions, we had made the same and experiment, and had to change that kind of floors.

Would it not be a wise thing to try and avoid mistakes made in some other schools?

May I ask you to be so kind as to give this matter your most careful consideration, and to give orders accordingly?

The flooring material that the Contractors have on hand is not the kind called for in their contract, but it has been accepted by the Architect. Part of this cheaper flooring could be put in the basement, and real good flooring should be bought for the Ground Floor.

I would like this new school to be a credit to your Department, and beyond criticism. Listening to criticism against Indian Department is about as insulting to me as if it were addressed to me personally.

Trusting you will give this my first official letter your kindest consideration,

I remain, Dear Sir, your most devoted

Honorable Sir,

Although you have been informed that the work on the new School here does not progress as fast as it might be expected nevertheless I am glad to say that the Department is not slow in attending to the out-buildings.

Mr. Mayo sent here by the Indian Commissioner, is now on the grounds and has started the building of the Barn, the only building for which he has any instructions so far. While Mr. Mayo is here, and has his men available, it seems to me that it would be most opportune to have him erect the other out-buildings.

There is required an Implement Shed, which should be 60ft. X 24ft.-At the other new Schools the Implement Shed has proved to be inadequate, and the size suggested is not out of proportion for all Machinery.

A Hen-House, 32ft.X16ft., is also required, without having to add any further comment.

Another building, which is absolutely necessary, is the house for the Farm-Instructor who is a married man with family. And it seems to me that this house should be built this Fall without delay, as we are expected to move into the new School in the beginning of the coming year or very early in the Spring. Now would be the proper time to have this house built. Mr. Mayo has already built such houses on different Reserves. In our case, I would suggest the Bungalow Style; 18ft.X34ft., giving an accommodation of five rooms.-I may add that if the new School building there is no accommodation available for the Farm-Instructor and his family, Please do take this particular item into serious consideration.

Mr. Mayo informs me that he will complete the building of the Barn in two or three weeks. Therefore if your Department decides to have the other buildings erected, be good enough to send your instructions to Mr. Mayo, as soon as possible. The erection of these buildings at the present time and conditions would certainly prove to be a great economy to the Department.

RE: Indian School, Onion Lake, Sask.

Gentlemen:

We are installing the electric wiring in the above school for Mr. S. Brown of Winnipeg, the General Contractor.

When estimating the work, we interpreted section fourteen of the specifications to mean that the conduit where occurring upon masonry shall be of rigid type, but elsewhere flexible conduit could be used.

We have shipped all the material required, and are about to send the electricians to install same and the question has now been raised as to whether this installation is entirely to your approval. We would point out that should it be necessary to install rigid conduits throughout the joists would have to be notched to allow of the installation, as the construction is of shiplap covered with metal ceiling.

We mention this as an added reason for permitting the use of flexible conduits, but speaking frankly, our main reason is that we estimated the job on this basis; have purchased material and have paid cartage on same to Onion Lake.

We would esteem it a favor if you would telegraph us your decision in the matter, so as to make as little delay as possible.

Yours very truly,

Dear Sir,

As Procurator for the Oblate Fathers, I have been visiting the R.C.Mission on the Onion Lake Reserve. And while here for the past three weeks, I had the occasion of seeing several times the new School now under construction.

Your Inspector for the works must have reported that this construction is progressing very slowly. Indeed the Contractor has lost a month, if not two months of very favorable weather during which he could have rushed the outside work, if he had employed a sufficient number of men, or paid the ordinary wages. The fact is that at the present only the boards have been put on the main part of the roof, and so far no pitch or gravel has been laid on same in order to have the inside of the building dry and fit to work inside. Even today very few men are on the job, and not very competent at that. I think something has to be done to compel the Contractor to move a little faster, if it is expected that the building will be ready for occupation in the spring.

Moreover it seems as if the Contractor is trying to evade many details of the Specifications and curtail the work. Fortunately the Inspector, Mr. Hamilton, a capable man, is constantly on the job and on the look out; in fact he scarcely dares to absent himself.

It appears even that the Contractor, wanting to pass over the head of the Inspector, claims to command influence with some Officials at Ottawa. So it might be advisable to follow up more closely.

I thought it my duty, Dear Sir, to call your attention to this matter, for the better interests of the Department, and for the sake of the School building itself which we are to occupy and manage.

Respectfully yours,

A. Haussman, O.M.I

Dear Sirs,

I hereby submit the following report on the progress made in the construction of the R C Indian Residential School here.

The work is going very slow, and as you mentioned in your letter of Aug 24th that the school according to the contract is to be completed by Dec 8th. I advised them to that effect but they do not seem to worry about it; they have not got half the number of men they should have, and when I objected to the delay they claimed they could not get suitable men for the work, and they promised to procure some men from outside of the district.

The main part of the building is closed in and the storm sash are mostly fitted, the rest of the building is not closed in yet owing to the delay of the heating boilers not being on the job and which has held up the cement work of boiler room. The heating boilers are now in place and the cement walls are about completed. The siding is being put on the main building and the painters are following up with their work. The plumbing work is being carried on as fast as can be expected under the circumstances. The weather during the past month has been very unfavorable for outside work as we have had some very cold weather and snow and there has been a lot of wind and rain. It will be some time yet before the lathing and plastering can be started, and as the weather may turn cold at any time now the heating plant should be in operation in case the weather should turn cold when the plastering is being done.

The sub contractor for the electric wiring shipped material here for their work and instead of sending rigid conduit they sent the flexible conduit. I objected to the change and took the matter up with the underwriter's association, and they wired me that rigid was the best and carried a better rate of insurance, so I notified the contractors to that effect and they are getting after the sub contractors re same.

The felt and gravel roofing contractors have not arrived yet but their material is all here, they are expected here next week. The material for the metal work has arrived and is being delivered to the site. The grading of the earth around the building is being done and should be completed in a couple of weeks.

The above report is respectfully submitted.

I remain

Your obedient servant

Dear Sirs,

As Inspector of Construction on the Roman Catholic Indian Residential School being erected here wish to make the following report.

I have done all in my power to get the contractors to have the building completed in the time specified in the contract and I took the matter up with Mr Brown and informed him that you insisted in having it completed by December 8th, and the only answer I could get was that there was no penalty mentioned in the contract but that they would complete the work as soon as they possibly could.

I received a telegram from you some time ago about having an engineer sent here from Calgary to lay out the Sewer and Water System and prepare plans for same but up to the present time there has been no one came yet. As the weather is very cold here just now it would be advisable to have the work started as soon as possible if it is to be done this winter. The rain water tank and sewer will need to be completed before the thaw and rain in the spring as the rain water down pipes from roof are connected and if the rain came it would flood the basement. In my estimation it would be better to have the excavating done now than in the spring as there is only about two feet of frost in the ground now but in the spring there will be over six feet.
