Dear Sirs,

I hereby wish to submit to you the following report on the construction of the Roman Catholic Indian Residential School here.

The weather has been very cold since the beginning of the month which has delayed the outside work considerably. The siding is all on with the exception of the rear end and the west side of the chapel. The siding which is in place has all received the first coat of paint and some of it has been seconded coated. There has not been anything done to the front and side verandahs yet except the cement piers. The inside work is going slowly, the first and second floors are about ready for plastering and the plasterer has started work at the first floor. The heating plant has been in operation since Dec 3rd. The plumbing is well advanced, the electrical work is keeping ahead of the lathers. The several subcontractors are doing their best to keep from holding up any of the work.

At the present time there are six carpenters and three helpers, three laborers, one electrician, two lathers, two steam fitters, one plumber and helper, two plasterers and three laborers.

The heating boilers should be washed out by this time but as the sewer has not been put in yet it is almost impossible to have it done under present conditions. In connection with the sewer it is very necessary to have it put in at the earliest possible time as I understand from the residents that there is generally a thaw about the middle of January, and if it comes this year and the rainwater pipes connected the water from the roofs will all go into the basement and will have a tendency to injure the foundation.

There has been nothing heard of the engineer who you notified me was coming in connection with the sewer and water system at the school.

The above report is respectfully submitted from

Your obedient servant

Dear Sirs,

I hereby submit the following report as Inspector of Construction at the Roman Catholic Indian Residential School here.

The first two days of the month was very cold, registering 54 below zero on Sunday and 42 below Monday, then turning milder on Tuesday and continued so till the 12th then turning colder with no change up to the present time.

The plastering is well advanced, the second floor is finished plastering, the first floor is completed with the exception of the two dormitories which is not quite in shape for the finish coat. The chapel is ready for the carpenters to put the finish on, the ground floor is receiving the finish coat of plaster where the first coat is in shape to receive it, the basement has not been first coated yet but they expect to start the beginning of the week.

There are no cement floors put in yet, the electrical contractor is well advanced with their work also the plumbing and heating contractor.

Since the mild weather set in the carpenters have been erecting the front verandah and which is well advanced.

At the present time there are six carpenters, two plasterers and a helper, one metal worker, one electrician, one plumber and helper four laborers, one truck driver and the general foreman.

Although the contractors are away behind the time that they were supposed to have the building completed they are going ahead as fast as they can at the present time under the circumstances.

The Sister Superior in charge of the mission school here made a request to the department some time ago for an extension to the verandah at the east end of the school, the request being turned down they have taken the matter up with the contractors who gave an estimate on the work, so they have asked the contractor to proceed with the work and for which they are paying for themselves and which is hoped will meet with your approval.

The above report is respectfully submitted by

Your obedient servant

Inspector of Construction

Dear Sirs,

I hereby wish to submit the following report re progress made in the erection of the Roman Catholic Indian Residential School here.

The Ironworkers and Painters arrived Feb 1st and have made satisfactory progress since, the painters are following up the ceiling men. At the present time the ceiling is in place at the ground, first and second floors, also the chapel ceiling and they are well advanced at basement ceiling.

The woodwork is also well advanced, the interior finish and doors is nearing completion and the painters have most of the work stained. Some of the tradesmen are working overtime.

The contractor is making arrangements to have the cement floors put in the basement, the main stairs are being erected also the finish floor is being laid in second floor.

The heating men are at work putting radiators in their permanent position wherever the work is advanced enough to allow them.

The plumbers have all their material prepared and in readiness to be installed when the carpenters and painters are advanced enough to allow them.

There is considerable outside work to be done yet but on account of the cold weather lately they have not been able to advance very fast.

The old Roman Catholic Mission School Buildings at Onion Lake were burnt to the ground Friday night Feb 10th, their church was also burnt and they are now without a school.

There has been no word received yet of the Engineer who is supposed to come here to lay out the sewer and water system and prepare plans for same, if possible this work should be rushed as the Mission is very anxious to get moved into the school and they ask that immediate steps be taken re the sewer and water system as they want this work done before they move in.

They ask for shelving in store rooms, kitchen, bakery & laundry also lockers in dormitories, seating in chapel also seats in the recreation rooms, there is no mention of this work in the specifications but if it is the intention of the department to have this work done for the mission I could have a list of the material for their requirements and get quotations on the material so that the work may be attended to as soon as the contractors had their work completed.

The above report is respectfully submitted and I await your further instructions. I remain

Your obedient servant

present. Those children whose homes are on the Onion Lake reserve have already been taken away by their parents.

With regard to the origin of the fire, nothing seems to be known. A strange circumstance is that earlier in the same day a fire was discovered in another part of the building, quite remote from where the fire later in the day broke out. It appears that about noon the girl's dormitory was seen to be full of smoke, and the Sisters investigating this, one of the beds was discovered to be on fire. The only possible cause can account for this fire is that perhaps a spark had flown from the stove to the bed earlier in the morning when the fire was lighted; and then when the bed had been made up, had been covered up, and had smouldered and later broken out in flame. The bed found afire was not far from the stove. This small fire was completely put out and I do not think can have any connection with the main one. It is possible that one or more of the school boys could have smoked up into the attic, where the fire came out, and perhaps have smoked there, but I cannot find that any did so. I do not think the fire can have originated from a spark from the chimney, which, although an old one, appeared sound. Most of the best clothing belonging to the institution was kept in the attic, and was a total loss.

After the children are taken away by their parents, I do not suppose there will be more than twenty left for the Sisters to look after; these will be quite comfortable in the old Anglican buildings, and can stay there until the new school is ready for occupation, when they can remove into it; and the other children can be brought back from their homes.

Sir,

I have the honour to confirm my telegram of the 10th, yesterday, reading as follows:

"Old Roman Catholic Residential School completely destroyed by fire this evening. Children and staff all safe. Children are being housed temporarily in old Anglican school. An writing."

and to report that at about 6 o'clock last evening an Indian passing the school noticed smoke rising from the roof of the building and at once informed the Sisters in charge, who immediately alarmed the whole neighbourhood. I hurried to the building, summoning all the help I could find. We found the fire burning in the attic over the boy's dormitory close to the chimney. At first it seemed possible that the building could be saved, but it was so difficult to get water to where it was needed, it having to be carried by hand up four flights of stairs inside, and up a long ladder on the outside, that the flames gained upon us, and the attempt to save the building had to be given up, and the energy of the workers directed to saving as much of the contents as possible; and by this means we managed to save a lot of the bedding and clothing, and most of the lighter articles of value. In the meantime the flames had spread rapidly, and we soon had to beat a hasty retreat from the main building. Our efforts were then directed to trying to save the church, about 50 feet west of the school, and the laundry and store buildings, about 50 feet north of the school. As the flames were driving westward the attempt to save the church had to be abandoned and the building was soon ablaze, but we were successful in saving the laundry and store buildings to the north; the Principal's residence was also saved.

I then spoke to the Rev. Father Balter, the principal, and the Sister Superior, with respect to how we should arrange to house the children and staff, and offered them the use of the old Anglican School buildings for the time being, which they gratefully accepted, and we have since removed all the bedding and other belongings saved, to that place.

As it appeared that the situation would be relieved considerably if the children could be taken to their homes, at the request of the Principal I have sent word to the outlying reserves for the parents to come to Onion Lake for their children and take them home for the present.

THE MARSHALL OIL ENGINE is a high-grade self-contained power generator on thoroughly practical lines, and is scientifically constructed for the effective and economic utilization of crude, refined and residual fuel oils. Marshall Oil Engines are widely and successfully employed as prime movers in all parts of the world for industrial and agricultural duties of all kinds, including driving machinery in factories, sawmills, brickyards, flour mills, elevators, laundries, creameries, and other places where space, cleanliness and economy are considerations. The engines are constructed in various sizes from 16 b.h.p. to 300 b.h.p. The sizes up to 25 b.h.p. are of horizontal design, and can if desired be mounted on trucks to form portable units. MARSHALL OIL ENGINES

CYCLE OF OPERATION

The Marshall Oil Engine Works on the Well-known Two Cycle Principle, Namely Every Other Stroke is a Power Stroke and the Degree of Cyclic Regularity is Very Marked.

The air for the cylinder "A" is silently drawn into the crankcase "B" through the air-valve "C" by the suction of the piston "D." During the power stroke, the air in the crankcase attains the required degree of compression. Just before the termination of the power stroke the piston "D" uncovers the exhaust ports "E" at the lower end of the cylinder, and the air ports "F" on the opposite side of the cylinder. Air under pressure from the crankcase rushes through the ports "F" and sweeps out the products of combustion through the exhaust ports and leaves the cylinder full of pure air.

The top of the piston is shaped to distribute the air to all parts of the cylinder, and this ensures efficient scavenging.

The piston then commences the compression stroke. At about the end of this stroke, the fuel is injected into the vaporizer "G" through the sprayer "H" in a fine spray which mixes thoroughly with the compressed air. A combustible mixture is thus formed and it is fired by the heat of the vaporizer and the compression pressure.

The Two Cycle Operation enables a regular turning effort to be obtained. The Flywheel receives an impulse every revolution which is given without shock, consequently very smooth working results and an even torque are obtained. This combination of ideal conditions in the MARSHALL ENGINE ensures remarkable smoothness of running, reliability, and capacity for making steady runs of long duration, with little attention.

The combustion is so complete that practically no deposit is formed; therefore the vaporizer and cylinder interior need very little cleaning.

The engine is so designed that water injection to the cylinder is not necessary under any conditions of working. The governor accurately times the moment of ignition as well as proportions the quantity of fuel injected. The vaporizer will remain sufficiently heated to ensure perfect ignition without the aid of the lamp even when the engine is running on light loads and no adjustment is required.

No air or exhaust valves are required in the cylinder head or the cylinder of the Marshall Oil Engine. By the elimination of such valves and their intricate operating gear, the chief trouble experienced with oil engines has been avoided. Moreover the number of working parts has been reduced to a minimum, with a consequent reduction in the wear and tear on the engine.

The cylinder is fitted with easily removable liners, which can be renewed if necessity should arise without the large expenses that would be incurred in replacing the complete cylinder.
MARSHALL OIL ENGINES

SYSTEM OF WORKING

MARSHALL OIL ENGINES operate on the successful and well-established two-stroke cycle, which is fully explained on page 6. To start the engine the vaporizer cap at the top of the cylinder must be heated for a few minutes with the lamp provided—a sufficiently high temperature for starting is quickly obtained. As soon as the engine is running at normal speed the lamp is no longer required. The vaporizer is correctly proportioned so that the combustion temperature is maintained at all loads.

A charge of air is compressed in the cylinder at a pressure of approximately 150 lbs. per square inch. This is sufficiently high to ensure maximum economy in working, but is not great enough to make starting a difficult operation. Self-starting apparatus is supplied with all the larger models.

At the correct moment oil fuel is injected in the form of a finely atomized spray. The temperature of the vaporizer, due to the heating lamp, or to previous explosions, suffices to fire the mixture. This simple method is so automatic in action that complicated ignition gear and continuous lamp heating are unnecessary.

The design of the Marshall Engine on the two-stroke principle successfully obtains the economy of the high compression oil engine, and with other advantages peculiar to the reduced pressures of the low compression engine it possesses a marked superiority over both types as regards simplicity in mechanical detail and operation. In the Marshall Engine there is no complicated ignition system and there are no valves—two sources of great trouble with many engines of other design.

The Marshall Engines will work on most mineral oils up to .92 specific gravity, but the best results are obtained from fuels with specific gravity of from .85 to .9 and a calorific value of not less than 19,000 B.T.U.'s per lb. With good crude oil, fuel consumption at full load is less than a half-pint per brake horsepower per hour, the consumption varying slightly according to the size of the engine, i.e., the larger the engine the greater the economy. (On three-quarter load the consumption would be increased about 6% and by about 20% on half-load.)

MARSHALL OIL ENGINES

GENERAL SPECIFICATIONS

THE MARSHALL OIL ENGINE is of massive proportions, all the working parts and bearing surfaces are of liberal dimensions, all components are readily accessible, and the engine is specially designed for heavy duty and for making long continuous runs. The engine is of totally enclosed design, and is capable of developing its rated load when running at the standard speed, and suitable crude or refined oil. The engine will also carry an overload of 10% for short periods.

The ENGINE BED is a massive and well supported casting with an oil channel at its base. The top facing is machined to take the cylinder trunk which forms the upper part of the crankcase and cylinder jacket. Also the bed is accurately bored to receive the main bearings.

The MAIN BEARINGS are of the split type, provided with adjustable steps of the finest grade anti-friction bearing metal, and are of most liberal dimensions. They are specially designed to ensure accessibility and perfect lubrication and to prevent leakage of oil.

The CRANKSHAFT is of substantial proportions, machined from mild steel forging and accurately balanced.

The CONNECTING ROD is a solid mild steel forging carefully machined and fitted with adjustable bearings at both ends.

The PISTON is made of close grained cast iron, of ample strength, provided with five "Ramsbottom" rings; it is fitted with a specially hardened steel pin to receive the connecting rod.
The CYLINDER is fitted with a detachable liner, formed of a separate casting of special close-grained metal, accurately bored and finished. This liner is easily removable, and is fitted into the cylinder casing in such a way as to make it watertight, and at the same time allow freedom for expansion and contraction as its temperature changes. The ports are arranged so that the piston correctly controls the periods of air admission and exhaust.

The bed and cylinder trunk together form an air-tight chamber and our own special air inlet valves are fitted at front and back of the trunk. No other valves are needed in the engine.

The VAPORIZER is of special design, carefully proportioned to ensure complete combustion, and the engine can be worked continuously for long periods without cleaning. The cylinder head is of simple construction. No air or exhaust valves are required and the stresses due to unequal expansion are thus avoided. Ample facilities are provided for cleaning the water-jacketed spaces.

The SHAFT GOVERNOR is of the centrifugal spring-loaded type, and highly sensitive. It operates by altering the length of the fuel pump stroke and the time that the fuel is injected; thus giving an explosion in the cylinder every revolution. The speed can be varied about 10% when the engine is running, i.e., about 6% below and 15% above normal.

The FUEL PUMP is of our own design, simple in construction, positive in action and adjusted to deliver the correct supply of fuel to the vaporizer on what is known as the solid injection principle; thereby dispensing with the use of compressed air for fuel injection. A distinct feature of the Marshall engines is that the governor and fuel pump are completely encased and work in an oil bath.

The LUBRICATING ARRANGEMENTS are exceptionally efficient, economical and complete in every respect. The system comprises: Oil rings to give automatic continuous lubrication to the main bearings; forced lubrication for the piston and pin; combined forced and centrifugal lubrication for the crank pin. All working parts not specially mentioned are provided with suitable means of lubrication.

The BALANCED FLY-WHEEL is of cast iron, of sufficient weight to ensure steady running, machined on face and edges of rim, and securely fixed on the crankshaft. The standard rotation is clockwise when viewing the engine from the governor end.

The PULLEY has sufficient width to drive on to fast and loose pulleys for the smaller sizes and on to a friction clutch pulley on the larger sizes, and is keyed to the crankshaft, which is provided with an authorised bearing and sole plate.

The FUEL TANK is of mild steel and fitted with cover and fine gauze strainer. It has a capacity for about six hours run on full load. It is arranged in two compartments so that when very heavy and thick fuel is used, the engine can be started up and shut down on a lighter grade of oil which flows readily through the suction pipes to the fuel pump.

An exhaust heated chamber is provided for heating the oil to accelerate its flow to the fuel pump. The chamber can be arranged so that it is cut out of circuit in warm climates, or when using light fuel oil.

STARTING APPARATUS—A reliable lamp is supplied for heating the vaporizer until the engine has started, after which the heat from the vaporizer is sufficient to ignite the fuel charge. A combined starting and charging valve with the necessary piping, pressure gauge, etc., is fitted, enabling the engine to be started by compressed air, stored at a pressure of 150 lbs. per square inch in a suitable air receiver, which is recharged by the engine when running.

Adequate COOLING is assured by means of a centrifugal pump belt-driven from the crankshaft circulating the water through the cylinder jackets.

A cast iron EXHAUST SILENCER is supplied to reduce to a minimum the noise of the exhaust. A short length of exhaust piping, suited to the standard arrangement of the engine, is supplied.

ACCESSORIES AND SPARES include a Starting Lamp, Oil Can, complete set of Wrenches, two Piston Rings, Nipple for Starting Lamp Burner, Ignition Tube, set of Joints and Packing Washers, two Air Valves for Crankcase, and set of Springs. An Instruction Book giving full information for the erection, working and management of the engine is supplied.

All materials are the best of their respective kinds; the engine is thoroughly painted and finished in first-class style; and the workmanship throughout is of the highest standard.

The Inspector Mr. Hamilton, since the burning of our school is pressing on the employes with the work and he would expect that all would be completed in five or six weeks, but nothing yet has been done for the installation of the water system, and we would be most thankful if you would be so kind as to urge on the contractors of this work to begin at once the installation of the said system. We deem it necessary to tell you how urgently we need the work completed. You realize that by yourself.

In case of fire it would be impossible to fight against the flames for lack of water. On the other hand, should there be a rainy spring season we will greatly be embarrassed to drain the water falling on the roof, which will certainly cause a great damage to the new building.

The water used at present is far from being pure; it leaves a deposit in the boilers. These boilers have to be cleaned out, and on this account too, the water system could not be differed any longer.

Other works also need to be completed such as the building of the farmer's house. The farm work will begin with the early spring, and at present there is no house wherein to lodge this hired man and family. Consequently this building should now be commenced so as to be completed in time.

Hoping that this request will meet with your kind approval, and that you will soon take the necessary step to have the work completed to the great satisfaction of the whole staff who is now so anxious to take possession of the new school. I remain dear Sir,

Dear Sir,

Your telegram of March 21st, received, but it throws no light on the question involved.

I am sorry to bother you directly and would prefer to deal through your inspector but owing to slow mail service up time will not permit. Our trouble is the Plumbing Contractor disputes the work of metal covering as he claims only slop sinks are specified in his specifications. We allowed for the carpentry of these tables as we realized no other tradesmen would have carpenters employed, but we did not make any allowance for metal covering as we naturally expected when same was not included in our portion of the specifications; it would be specified under the Plumbers or the Gal. Iron specifications.

If this was only a question of a few dollars we would not bother you, but owing to the high price of Copper the best estimate is $300.00 providing it is done immediately before the tradesmen get away. If a special trip had to be made it would cost considerable more.

However, I will make it clear to you we are not soliciting extras. If you can verify the fact this work is covered under Plumbers or Gal. Iron specifications we will have same executed and charge against their contract.

Wire immediately on receipt of this letter as any extra expense can be avoided.

Dear Sirs

I hereby wish to submit the following report on the progress made by the contractors in connection with the erection of the Roman Catholic Indian Residential School here.

The work has been progressing fairly well lately, the carpenterwork at the second floor rooms is completed with the exception of the window stops which have just arrived from the factory, the painter has the floors oiled first coat and other woodwork stained and one coat of varnish, the ceilings are completed.

The first floor carpenterwork is completed with the exception of the window stops, the hanging of the sun room sash and the steps from corridor and toilet rooms to dormitories. The painter has dormitory floors oiled and other room floors first coated, the other woodwork is stained and first coat of varnish on, the ceilings are nearing completion.

The ground floor carpenterwork is well advanced, the flooring is in place with the exception of the corridors, all the room floors are finished and first coated, the other woodwork is mostly in place and stained, the chapel woodwork is about completed and stained, the gallery rail has not arrived yet, the ceiling is about completed painting.

The basement work is not as far advanced as the other part of the building, the cement floor is being put in, the finish coat is placed in one of the recreation rooms, both toilet and bath rooms, kitchen, bakery, two store rooms and corridors, the toilet and bath room partitions are in place in the girls side. There is nothing done yet at cement floors in the machinery room, boiler room, fuel room, laundry room and pupils dining room, other rooms are ready to receive the finish coat, the cement base work is well advanced, the majority of the woodwork is to be done yet in the basement.

There is considerable carpenterwork to be done on the outside, and about two thirds of the painting to be done which cannot be done till the weather turns warmer, there is also some cement work and plastering to be done on the outside which cannot be done till the frost is out of the walls.

The plumbing fixtures are being put in place and at the present time are all in place on ground, first and second floors, & heating radiators are put in their permanent positions on above floors.

The above report is respectfully submitted by

Your obedient servant

Inspector of Construction

Onion Lake, April 12th, 1928.

To the Honorable Duncan Scott,

Deputy minister of Indians Affairs,
Ottawa.

Dear Sir,- Allow me to refer you to a letter I wrote to you last year concerning the advisability of providing a house for the Principal of our Residential School at Onion Lake.

To the reasons brought forth in my previous letter in favor of this project, I will take the liberty to add some others which I consider worthy of your attention. The Principal should have a residence of his own, on the ground that being a missionary in charge of the Indians on the Reserve, his activities therefore are not exclusively limited to the administration of the school, but also to the spiritual welfare of the Indians on the Reserve on which the school is located. This fact necessitates on his part almost daily relations with the Indians in matters out of his concern as Principal.

This situation emerging from this double ministry is inherent to the system in vogue in every school built on every Reserve. In the Indian Reserves where the school is erected, and it is the case for almost all the Residential schools, If I am well informed, the situation is the same for the clergymen of every denomination. Besides being the Principal of the school the clergyman is more-over in charge of the spiritual care of the Indians.

As I said this double charge imposes upon the Principal duties which have nothing to do with the govern of the school. You will readily understand that in such a situation the Principal would far better had he a house of his own in order to attend to matters quite irrelevant to his duties as Principal. It would certainly do away with all kinds of inconveniences and render his position more suitable to his calling as minister of the Gospel.

Furthermore I will take this opportunity to point out to you another consideration which cannot too easily be discarded, that is, that the Father in charge of the School is living under the same roof as the Sisters. Needless for me to stress this point except to make you aware of the wishes of the Episcopate, that the Fathers should live in a separate building. The fact that this point has not been heretofore strongly emphasized by the Bishops, does not in the least alter its importance.

For these reasons added to those in my previous letter, I take the liberty to renew my demand for an appropriation for the building of a residence for the Principal of Onion Lake's Residential School.

Two thousand dollars would cover the expenses and we ourselves could attend to the plan and construction of this residence, if the Department consent.

Hoping that you will consider our demand favorably and thanking you for this and past favors,

I am, Your's truly,

ONION LAKE R. C. RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL.

As you are aware, the old school building was burnt down completely, together with their church on February the 10th. The cause of the fire, which started about six o'clock in the evening in the attic, is unknown. The Sisters and seven of the pupils are now occupying the building formerly used by the boys at the old Anglican School. They were busily engaged while I was there preparing clothing and bedding material to replace that which was burnt. I looked over the new school building and noted that a great deal of work will have to be done before it will be ready for occupancy. Nothing had been done towards installing water or sewerage. There was a great deal of finishing to do to the interior of the building and more than half of the cement floor in the basement had to be laid. I examined the new barn and found that it is very well built, proper ventilation provided and stanchions are properly installed. It is a real good building. This is the only outbuilding, so far, which has been erected.

The foregoing report is respectfully submitted.

Dear Sirs,

I hereby wish to submit the following report on the progress made by the contractors in the construction of the Roman Catholic Indian Residential School here.

The interior woodwork is nearing completion, the first and second floors are practically complete with the exception of the wash tables in the dormitories and some touching up on the walls and floors; the finish coat of varnish is on the woodwork and floors.

The ground floor woodwork is about completed, the finish coat of varnish is on the centre part of the building also the chapel, the basement woodwork is nearing completion and the painters are well advanced with their work.

There is no cement floor put in the machinery room as the work cannot be done till the foundation for the electric light plant is put in. The laundry machinery is not set up yet and the shafting is not in place awaiting the location of the engine.

There is considerable work to be done at the outside of the building, the cement walls are all to be plastered from the grade line up to the top of the wall, the outside painting is held up on account of the unfavorable weather conditions, some parts of the building have not even received the priming coat.

The plumbing work is nearing completion and the heating system is well advanced, the sub-contractor on heating claims that it is impossible to wash out the boilers and give them the proper test till the sewer and water system is installed.

Mr Hudson of the firm of Brown and Hudson who handled the work here left the job on April 7th leaving one carpenter on the job to finish the work. At the present time there are three painters, two plumbing and heating men and one carpenter at work.

Mr R H Goodchild, the engineer from the Dominion Water Power Board of Calgary visited the site on March 30th and took the levels and whatever other information he required in connection with the water and sewage system for the school and left for Calgary on March 31st, and I am in hopes that something will be done immediately, especially with the sewer for it will be serious if the sewer work is not done before the spring rains come.

The above report is respectfully submitted by

Your obedient servant

GENERAL

The new Onion Lake R.C.School, now nearing completion, is situated about thirty miles north and five miles west of the Town of Lloydminster, Sask., on the Onion Lake Reserve, some eight miles north of the North Saskatchewan river.

It is a frame building, designed to accommodate 80 pupils, and when completed will have a value of approximately $80,000.

The builder's contract does not call for a water supply nor sewage disposal system and it is the purpose of this report to outline such systems and to estimate the cost of the completed works.

As intimated, the School has been designed to accommodate eighty pupils, and it is therefore considered
desirable to design a plant capable of serving one hundred persons.

WATER SUPPLY SYSTEM.

Water Requirements for domestic purposes.

The amount of water required per day on a basis of 40 U.S.gallons per capita per day will be

\[ 40 \times 100 = 4,000 \text{ U.S.gals. per day.} \]

It is considered that a supply of 30 gals. per minute will supply the maximum demand.

Water Requirements for Fire Protection Purposes.

On account of the value of this building, its purpose, and its construction a very adequate system of fire protection should be installed.

To successfully cope with a fire in the building it is considered that at least four streams of about eighty gallons per minute each at a pressure of not less than 50 lbs. playing simultaneously would be necessary, and that it should be possible to maintain this flow for an hour.

It is considered that if the fire could not be conquered in one hour that the building could not be saved.

Water Requirements for Laundry Purposes.

It is proposed to conserve the rain water from the roof by means of a concrete tank fed from the roof drain and to use this rainwater in the laundry. The amount of water required will be large and the tank has been designed accordingly.
SOURCE OF SUPPLY.

For domestic and fire fighting purposes the only possible supply is a small spring situated in a draw about four hundred feet south of the School. This spring has a flow of about fifteen gallons per minute.

The water is clear and cold and not too hard for ordinary washing purposes.

A lake about half a mile in diameter lies about three hundred yards from the School to the South west, but on account of its low elevation and distance the cost of using this lake as a source of water for fire fighting purposes would be prohibitive.

The cost of the pumping plant necessary would be nearly seven thousand dollars.

Proposed Works Water Supply System.

Domestic Supply.

As the flow of the spring is so small and, as it is the only sure supply of usable water for all purposes, it is considered necessary to construct a sizable well or tank at the spring from which well to pump to a reservoir at the School.

This well will be of reinforced concrete and will measure - at the bottom 16'x10', and it will be 12' deep. A manhole will be placed in the top and over the north end of this structure, a pumphouse 8'x13' and 8' high will be erected to house the pumping machinery necessary to raise the water to the upper reservoir.

The details of construction are shown on the
plans, and the details of all machinery are shown in the estimates appended hereto. This building is to be provided with a stove for winter use. The upper reservoir will also be of reinforced concrete construction, and it will be located 12' east of the building, opposite the engine room.

From this reservoir, by means of a small pump electrically driven, water will be pumped to two pressure tanks - placed in series - situated inside the building and this plant will have an automatic control, which will keep the pressure between 20 and 40 lbs. at all times.

These pressure tanks will be coupled to the plumbing system already installed.

The combined capacity of these two tanks is about 1700 U.S.gals.

FIRE PROTECTION SYSTEM.

To adequately protect the building from fire an independent pumping plant will have to be installed and coupled to the standpipe system, already in place.

It is, as has been stated, considered desirable to have at least four effective fire streams available for use simultaneously, each throwing a stream of about 80 gals. per minute.

In order to ensure safe operation of the pumping plant required, it will be necessary to house it outside the School building, and it is proposed to erect the necessary pumphouse just south of the upper reservoir from which the supply will be drawn.

The plant recommended will have a capacity of 336 U.S.gals. per minute and to maintain this flow for an hour, a
supply of 336 x 60 or 20,160 U.S.gals. will be required.

The tank designed by the writer has a capacity of 21,500 U.S.gals.

It may be added that the actual supply for fighting a fire will be augmented by the amount which the pump at the spring can deliver to the reservoir in one hour, i.e., about 2,500 U.S.gals. making a total of 24,000 U.S.gals. available for immediate use.

It is also proposed to couple the pressure tanks to the stand-pipe system, and so make the contents of these tanks available for instant use to quench an incipient blaze and so preventing loss of time pending the starting of the outside plant.

As a further safeguard, it is recommended that three soda and acid fire extinguishers be placed, one in the boiler or engine room, one in the laundry and one in the kitchen, as these are the three places in which fire is most likely to break out, and the number suggested might well be doubled.

RAINWATER SYSTEM

To conserve the rainwater from the roof and to create a supply which would carry over the dry season it is proposed to construct a reinforced concrete tank reservoir, of the same design and size as the well at the spring.

This tank will have to be set 5' below the surface to prevent freezing during the cold weather. The roof drain will, of course, drain directly into this tank and the overflow from the tank will flow into the sewer from the boiler room.

The equipment to serve the laundry from this tank will
consist of a small pumping plant, electrically operated, so designed that the turning of a faucet will automatically start the motor and pump, causing an almost instantaneous flow.

It is considered that the system outlined above will meet all the requirements and it is recommended that it be adopted.

(sgd) R.H.GOODCHILD.

REPORT
on
SEWAGE DISPOSAL SYSTEM,
Onion Lake Indian (R.C.) School.

GENERAL:
This school is situated on high ground which slopes rapidly away from the School on three sides, and the design of a suitable sewage disposal system is therefore comparatively simple.

Plans and profiles of the proposed works together with estimates of cost accompany this report.

To the west of the School the land slopes to a short but steep draw and it is considered that this draw presents an excellent site for the sewage disposal bed and the system is designed with that point in view.

This School when completed will house some 100 persons, and the plant has been so designed as to care for that number of persons.

GENERAL DESIGN:
As shown on the general plan the 2 sewers from the school come together at the upper side of the disposal beds at a point 350' from the school.

The sewage from the toilets, baths, etc., passes through a septic tank, some 160' west of the School before being passed out to the disposal bed.

Pipe Lines:
The piping proposed for the sewer lines is 6"
glazed tile and that for the disposal bed 4" open tile drain pipe.

**SEPTIC TANK.**

The septic tank proposed is made up of two chambers, the settling chamber or septic tank proper and the syphon chamber. To render the structure as nearly permanent as possible it is of reinforced concrete throughout.

The affluent enters the septic tank a foot below the surface in order to prevent disturbance of the scum.

From the septic tank the sewage flows first through a set of grids, placed so as to intercept any sizable solid, and then over the dividing wall between the two chambers; two baffle boards are carried below the surface thus preventing undue disturbance.

Two three inch Anthes syphons designed to operate under an 18" head take care of the effluent from the chamber and deliver it to the discharge pipe.

It is estimated that this syphon chamber will carry about 450 imperial gallons before discharging.

**DISPOSAL BED.**

A manhole is proposed at the end of the two sewers where they lie side by side in the same trench, and from each side of this manhole to lay a line of 4" open tile drain to a distance of 30 feet.

These branches will be so located as to have a
good fall. It is proposed to lay this pipe on a 3' deep trench, leaving the trench open.

From this upper line of drain it is proposed to open up four straight trenches running obliquely down the slope for a distance of 50 ft. and to lay 4" open tile drain in these trenches. It is proposed to leave these trenches also open.

All the points of these tile drains will be covered with gravel to protect them from debris, etc.

The advantage in leaving these drains open is that when they become no longer serviceable they may be easily filled in and new ones opened up.

MANHOLES.

One manhole only will be required and this will be small and inexpensive.

It will be of concrete and will be provided with a cast iron cover.

It is recommended that the system outlined above be adopted as being the most suitable.

(signed) R.H. GOODCHILD.

SUPPLY OF MATERIAL AND EQUIPMENT -

The contractor will supply all material and equipment which enter into and form part of the finished structures, and all material required for the construction and maintenance of forms and the like.

Transport: The contractor will transport all material and equipment from the Railway station to the site of the work. The cost of transport will be included in the contract price for "Material Supplied" and "Equipment Supplied".

Care of Material: All material must be properly stored and cared for at all times. It will be subject to inspection before being used and if any is found to be damaged or in any way rendered useless or unsuitable it will be condemned and must immediately be removed from the work and replaced by suitable material by the Contractor at his sole expense.

SNOW, ICE AND DEBRIS -

Snow, Ice and Debris and foreign matter must be removed from the work whenever ordered by The Engineer, such removal being at the Contractor's expense.

FORMS -

Forms, where necessary, will be furnished and built by the Contractor and included in the contract price per cu.yd. of concrete.

Materials in forms may be used repeatedly but if so used shall be thoroughly cleaned after each time used and before setting up again. Before any concrete is poured
against them the moulding surface must be smeared with mineral oil or grease, or soap, in order to prevent the concrete from adhering to the forms.

Forms must be left in place until the concrete has set sufficiently to be safe from damage, either in process of removal, or from lack of support or from any other cause. The method employed in removal of forms must be such as to offer the minimum possibility of damaging the soft concrete; using soft concrete as a fulcrum for prying forms loose is specially forbidden.

REINFORCEMENT-

The contractor will provide, fabricate and fix in place all reinforcement shown on the drawings or required by reason of the methods of construction adopted by him. He must take whatever precautions are necessary, or are ordered by the Engineer, to maintain such reinforcement in its proper position while pouring concrete and afterward until the concrete is set.

Materials: Unless otherwise shown on the drawing or permitted by the District Engineer all reinforcement will be round steel bars meeting the requirements of the Standard Specifications of the American Society for Testing Materials for "Billet Steel Concrete Re-inforcement Bars (Serial designation A-19)" as adopted 1911 with all subsequent revisions.

Fabrication: The Contractor will do all work necessary in connection with cutting, bending, erection, tying, splicing and anchoring.

Bending: Wherever bars are shown on the drawing as bent to any shape, such bars will be bent cold (except anchors), using a suitable tool or appliance for the purpose.

Maintenance: All reinforcement must be so supported that it cannot be displaced before during or after the operation of pouring the concrete.

CONCRETE-

Materials, plant, labour, tools and appliances for proportioning, mixing, transporting, placing and finishing concrete will be supplied by the Contractor.

Materials: All material supplied will be tested and if defective must be immediately removed from the work and made good at the contractor's expense. Rejected material, if not removed within four days, may be destroyed or rendered useless by the Engineer.

Aggregate: The aggregate for concrete will consist of sound particles of silicious or calcareous rock.
particles must be free from hard adhering films or coatings of deleterious matter, such as clay, salts or vegetable acids.

Cement: All cement must comply with the requirements of the "Specification for Portland Cement" of the American Society for Testing Materials, as adopted September 1st, 1916, and all subsequent amendments or the Standards of the Engineering Institute of Canada. Cement may be shipped in bags or barrels at the option of the Contractor.

Transport and Storage: Cement must be protected from the weather during transport and at all times. It must be stored as directed by the engineer in charge and be subject to inspection at any time. If found defective the whole or such part as the engineer may direct must be immediately removed from the work and replaced with new cement at the contractor's expense.

Reinforced concrete (which for this purpose is defined as all concrete members in which steel is employed, to take certain definite stresses which the concrete itself is incapable of taking) will be mixed in the proportion of one part of cement to two parts of fine aggregate and four parts of coarse aggregate, measured dry. Each bag of cement will be considered as one cubic foot and each barrel as four cubic feet and the volume of aggregate adjusted accordingly.

Mass concrete (which for this purpose is defined as all concrete members in which all direct stresses are borne by the concrete unaided although steel may be employed for temperature, shrinkage or other reasons) will be mixed in the proportion of one part of cement, two and one half parts fine aggregate and five parts of coarse aggregate. Packages of cement will count for volume as above specified.

Maximum sizes of aggregate in reinforced work will not exceed one and one half inches in greatest dimension. For mass concrete no particle may be used greater in longest dimension than two tenths (2/10) of the least dimension of the member for which the concrete is intended.

Consistency: Sufficient water will be used in mixing concrete to give a mixture which will flow (not slide) readily on a plank surface inclined at 25 degrees to the horizontal. For reinforced work, especially in vertical members such as walls, slabs, counterforts, and columns, the concrete must be mixed sufficiently fluid to flow readily into corners and angles and about the reinforcing steel and to fill all voids.

Finish: After removal of forms, the surface will be carefully examined for exposed reinforcement. All holes, open voids, or pockets will be filled with stiff mortar mixed one to one and rammed in hard. Tie wires will be clipped off neatly flush with the surface. Bolt holes will be carefully cleaned out by a jet of water, air or steam under pressure, and filled with stiff mortar. The whole surface of all members, except floors, will be painted with neat grout.
Excavation of Trenches: The trenches in which the pipes are to be laid shall be excavated on the lines shown on the plan. There shall be no bends or undulations made other than those shown on plan or permitted by the Engineer.

All trenches shall be of sufficient width to permit proper jointing of the pipes. Bell holes at joints shall be excavated below the bottom of the trench, of sufficient size to allow ample room for the proper caulking of the joints, and so that the body of the pipe shall rest on solid ground throughout its length.

All necessary shoring and bracing shall be done by the Contractor to prevent movement in the sides of the excavation and all timber required as well as all necessary labour in connection with it shall be furnished by the Contractor as part of the Contract.

All water shall be removed by the Contractor from the trenches by pumping or other means, and the trench must be kept perfectly free from water when the jointing of the pipe is being done.

Backfilling Trenches: No backfilling shall be done until the pipes laid and jointed have been inspected and approved of by the Engineer.

After permission has been given, the trench shall be filled with selected earth free from stones and rubbish to a depth of at least two feet above the top of the pipe, thoroughly consolidated and compacted by ramming with suitable tools.

After the pipes have been covered with two feet of filling as specified, the remainder of the trench may be filled by hand, team or machinery. No large stones shall be allowed to be placed in the trench.

Coating Pipes: All galvanized pipes will have a heavy coating of hot coal tar or pitch applied before being jointed.

Joints: All vitrified tile drain pipes are to be laid from lower end up and the contractor will see that each length of pipe is clean before being laid. A gasket of hemp or jute of sufficient size will be inserted between the hub and spigot and properly rammed so that a space 1" in depth shall remain for cement mortar, to be inserted. The space between the spigot and hub shall be completely filled with mortar thoroughly pressed in all around and every precaution taken to secure a water-tight joint. The mortar shall be applied with a rubber trowel, a rammer, or compacted with a wooden caulking tool. Joints shall be finished all around with a neat level. The interior of each pipe joint shall be scraped clean of all projecting material.

Sir:

In further reference to the plans and specifications prepared in this office in connection with the water supply and sewerage disposal scheme for the Roman Catholic Indian Residential School at Onion Lake, Alberta.

We wired you on the 25th instant that tenders had been received from Messrs. Bennett and White and from Mr. John Towers, both of this city, giving you the figures submitted. We have since revised the plans submitted and are now submitting an alternative scheme which includes a revision of the original plans in that the capacity of the tanks has been considerably reduced. The storage reservoir at the springs was revised in capacity from 15,700 U.S. gallons to 5,000 U.S. gallons. The rainwater tank originally shown on the plans previously submitted, having a capacity of 15,700 U.S. gallons has been altered to show a capacity of 10,600 U.S. gallons. These changes, if carried out, will mean a saving on the estimated figures of the lowest bidder; i.e., Mr. John Towers, of some $1,066.09.

I am also submitting for your information a memorandum which has been prepared by Mr. Goodchild and which analyzes the tenders submitted by Messrs. Brown and Hudson of Winnipeg and those submitted by the Calgary firm. From this analysis it will be noted that certain essentials were omitted from the original specifications and therefore from the tender submitted by Messrs. Brown and Hudson. These omissions have been estimated for and a new figure prepared, which brings the bid of Messrs. Brown and Hudson to $17,138, which very closely approximates the average of the other bids received. The lowest tender is still that of Mr. John Towers of Calgary.

We are also forwarding two copies of the tenders submitted by Mr. John Towers and Messrs. Bennett and White; also one copy of the "Specifications" and "Information for Bidders", which were omitted from our letter of the 26th inst. An independent estimate prepared by Mr. Goodchild in duplicate which was asked for in your telegram of the 25th instant, is also enclosed.

An alternative bid has also been received from Mr. John Towers, which covers the proposed reduction in capacity of the tanks referred to in the first part of this letter. Copy of this bid is likewise attached.

Memorandum:

With reference to the Dominion Water Power Branch proposal for the water supply and sewage disposal at the new Onion Lake R. C. Indian Residential School, I have to report that, after discussion with both Mr. Chene and Mr. Orr, there is nothing unnecessary recommended. Memorandum:

HONOURABLE CHARLES STEWART,

The new building for the Onion Lake R.C. Indian Residential School is practically completed. It was necessary to wait for the spring to secure a recommendation of the Dominion Water Power and Reclamation Service in connection with a water supply and sewerage system. Dear Sirs,

I hereby submit the following report re the construction of the Roman Catholic Indian Residential School here.

The plumbing and heating work is completed with the exception of the testing of the plant, the men has left for home but will return for the test as soon as the sewer is in.

The painting is going very slow owing to a dispute between the general contractor and the sub-contractor re the painting contract and at the present time the sub-contractor is in Winnipeg trying to arrange a settlement.

Mr Hudson arrived here from Winnipeg May the 3rd & brought a plasterer and cement worker to have some work done over which was unsatisfactory.

The plans of base for the electric lighting plant arrived and I am having the excavations made and the concrete put in. The plant is expected in Lloydminster any day now and have made arrangements to have it hauled to the school.

The staff of the Roman Catholic Mission have moved in to part of the building as they have a lot of work to do which cannot be attended to as their temporary quarters are so far away from here.

I am doing all that is possible to have the contract completed and from what I can see there is only about ten days work to do to complete the work if the contractor would see that the sub-contractors got their work cleaned up.

The electrician is here installing the fixtures which will be completed early next week providing there is no delay in the arrival of the balance of the material.

There has been no word lately in reference to the sewer and water system and the mission folks are very anxious to know what is being done, so if you could give any information re the above it would be greatly appreciated.

Sir:

Re: Onion Lake School Sewer.

I wired you today to the effect that it is very desirable to extend the sewage disposal system a distance of one hundred and fifty feet, so that the disposal beds will be at "the foot of the slope."

Mr. Towers agree with me that this should be done and you may remember—or Mr. Jennings will, I think, that the layout originally proposed by me called for such a location for the disposal beds.

I may say that Mr. Towers, as soon as he saw the proposed location, expressed the opinion that the system would work far better at the bottom of the steep slope, at a place where the fall is comparatively gentle, and the writer has always felt that this was so.

In order that this work may be done without delay I wired you setting Monday morning as a time limit, as Mr. Towers will be ready to begin the work at this point at that time.

I discussed the question with Mr. Hamilton, the Superintendent of Construction, and he expressed the opinion that one hundred dollars was a very reasonable figure for the extra work; i.e., 150' of trench (covered) and 150' 4" weeping tile drain pipe.

With reference to the grades of the sewer lines, it has been found necessary to alter them very materially due to the fact that the information supplied previously to the writer was not correct; and there are no plans in existence which show the elevations of piping, sewer outlets, etc., according to Mr. Hamilton.

The boiler room sewer with which the new sewer must be connected is eleven feet underground and this will mean much heavier work than was expected and calculated for.

Mr. Towers, of course, cannot take this extra cut out for the contract price, and the sewer must of necessity be placed at the depth mentioned.

Towers has generously offered to excavate up to a depth of seven feet at contract price and to take out the additional cut in excess of that figure on a cost + 15 per cent basis.

I may say that the excess over seven feet is for a distance of 175' only, so the extra cost will be small.

Will you kindly take the necessary steps to have this arrangement approved and advise both Mr. Towers and myself if you approve and can so arrange it.

GENERAL SPECIFICATIONS.

1.0 The work to be done and the material and equipment to be supplied include the following:

1.1 Excavate for and erect a wall and footing of mass concrete which is to act as a holdup or dam for the discharge of the spring. The west 15 feet of the dam to be carried down to the extra depth as shown on plan. To excavate and dig sump shown on plan on north side of dam which will extend for 10 feet along the dam back from the dam a distance equal to the length of the reservoir. This sump to be filled in for a depth of 6 feet with clean gravel which is to act as a filter for the water entering the reservoir.

1.2 Excavate for and erect a reinforced concrete reservoir at the west end of the stop wall as shown on plan. Erect over the north 8 feet of the reservoir a building for housing pumping equipment. Reservoir wall to be backfilled when completed and the unhoused portion of the top to be backfilled to the natural ground level.

1.3 Excavate and lay a 3" galvanized wrought steel pipeline, at the grades and depths shown on profiles, from the reservoir at east side of building. This line to be provided with a valve and connections to enable the entire line to be drained. The portion of the line extending from the pump house at spring to a point where seven feet of cover is obtained to be protected as shown on plans. Entire line to be backfilled when laying of pipe has been completed, to the level of the natural ground surface.

1.4 Excavate for and erect a reinforced concrete reservoir on the water supply line at a point 12 feet east of building as shown on plan. When complete back fill to the elevation of the natural ground surface, approximately 6.0 feet.

SUPPLY OF MATERIAL AND EQUIPMENT -

4.0 The contractor will supply all material and equipment which enter into and form part of the finished structures, and all material required for the construction and maintenance of forms and the like.

4.1 Transport: The contractor will transport all material and equipment from the Railway station to the site of the work. The cost of transport will be included in the contract price for "Material Supplied" and "Equipment Supplied".

4.2 Care of Material: All material must be properly stored and cared for at all times. It will be subject to inspection before being used and if any is found to be damaged or in any way rendered useless or unsuitable it will be condemned and must immediately be removed from the work and replaced by suitable material by the Contractor at his sole expense.

SNOW, ICE AND DEBRIS -

5.0 Snow, Ice and Debris and foreign matter must be removed from the work whenever ordered by the Engineer, such removal being at the Contractor's expense.

FORMS -

6.0 Forms, where necessary, will be furnished and built by the Contractor and included in the contract price per cu. yd. of concrete.

6.1 Materials in forms may be used repeatedly but if so used shall be thoroughly cleaned after each time used and before setting up again. Before any concrete is poured against them the moulding surface must be speared with mineral oil or grease, or soap, in order to prevent the concrete from adhering to the forms.
6.2 Forms must be left in place until the concrete has set sufficiently to be safe from damage, either in process of removal or from lack of support or from any other cause. The method of supporting and removing forms must be such as to offer the minimum possibility of damaging the soft concrete; using soft concrete as a fulcrum for prying forms loose is specially forbidden.

REINFORCEMENT -

7.0 The contractor will provide, fabricate and fix in place all reinforcement shown on the drawings or required by reason of the methods of construction adopted by him. He must take whatever precautions are necessary, or are ordered by the Engineer, to maintain such reinforcement in its proper position while pouring concrete and afterward until the concrete is set.

7.1 Material: Unless otherwise shown on the drawing or permitted by the District Engineer all reinforcement will be round steel bars meeting the requirements of the Standards Specification of the American Society for Testing Materials for "Billet Steel Concrete Reinforcement Bars (Serial designation A-15)" as adopted 1911 with all subsequent revisions.

7.2 Fabrication: The Contractor will do all work necessary in connection with cutting, bending, erection, tying, splicing and anchoring.

7.3 Bending: Wherever bars are shown on the drawing as bent to any shape, such bars will be bent cold (except anchors) using a suitable tool or appliance for the purpose.

7.4 Maintenance: All reinforcement must be so supported that it cannot be displaced before during or after the operation of pouring the concrete.

CONCRETE -

8.0 Materials, plant, labour, tools and appliances for proportioning, mixing, transporting, placing and finishing concrete will be supplied by the Contractor.

8.1 Materials: All material supplied will be tested and if defective must be immediately moved from the work and made good at the contractor's expense. Rejected material, if not removed within four days, may be destroyed or rendered useless by the Engineer.

8.2 Aggregate: The aggregate for concrete will consist of sound particles of silicious or calcareous rock. The particles must be free from hard adhering films or coatings of deleterious matter, such as clay, salts or vegetable acids.

8.3 Cement: All cement must comply with the requirements of the "Specification for Portland Cement" of the American Society for Testing Materials, as adopted September 1st, 1916, and all subsequent amendments or the Standards of the Engineering Institute of Canada. Cement may be shipped in bags or barrels at the option of the Contractor.
8.4 Transport and Storage: Cement must be protected from the weather during transport and at all times. It must be stored as directed by the engineer in charge and be subject to inspection at any time. If found defective the whole or such part as the engineer may direct must be immediately removed from the work and replaced with new cement at the contractor's expense.

8.5 Reinforced concrete (which for this purpose is defined as all concrete members in which steel is employed, to take certain definite stresses which the concrete itself is incapable of taking) will be mixed in the proportion of one part of cement to two parts of fine aggregate and four parts of coarse aggregate, measured dry. Each bag of cement will be considered as one cubic foot and each barrel as four cubic feet and the volume of aggregate adjusted accordingly.

8.6 Mass concrete (which for this purpose is defined as all concrete members in which all direct stresses are borne by the concrete unaided although steel may be employed for temperature, shrinkage or other reasons) will be mixed in the proportion of one part of cement, two and one half parts fine aggregate and five parts of coarse aggregate. Packages of cement will count for volume as above specified.

8.7 Maximum sizes of aggregate in reinforced work will not exceed one and one half inches in greatest dimension. For mass concrete no particle may be used greater in longest dimension than two tenths (2/10) of the least dimension of the member for which the concrete is intended.

8.8 Consistency: Sufficient water will be used in mixing concrete to give a mixture which will flow (not slide) readily on a plank surface inclined at 25 degrees to the horizontal. For reinforced work, especially in vertical members such as walls, slabs, counterforts, and columns, the concrete must be mixed sufficiently fluid to flow readily into corners and angles and about the reinforcing steel and to fill all voids.

8.9 Finish: After removal of forms, the surface will be carefully examined for exposed reinforcement. All holes, open voids, or pockets will be filled with stiff mortar mixed one to one and rammed in hard. The wires will be clipped off neatly flush with the surface. Bolt holes will be carefully cleaned out by a jet of water, air or steam under pressure, and filled with stiff mortar. The visible surface of all members, except floors, will be painted with neat grout.

9.0 Excavation of Trenches: The trenches in which the pipes are to be laid shall be excavated on the lines shown on the plan. There shall be no bends or undulations made other than those shown on plan or permitted by the Engineer.

All trenches shall be of sufficient width to permit of proper jointing of the pipes. Bell holes at joints shall
be excavated below the bottom of the trench, of sufficient size to allow ample room for the proper caulking of the joints, and so that the body of the pipe shall rest on solid ground throughout its length.

All necessary shoring and bracing shall be done by the Contractor to prevent movement in the sides of the excavation and all timber required as well as all necessary labour in connection with it shall be furnished by the Contractor as part of the Contract.

All water shall be removed by the Contractor from the trenches by pumping or other means, and the trench must be kept perfectly free from water when the jointing of the pipe is being done.

10.0 Backfilling Trenches: No backfilling shall be done until the pipes laid and jointed have been inspected and approved of by the Engineer.

After permission has been given, the trench shall be filled with selected earth free from stones and rubbish to a depth of at least two feet above the top of the pipe, thoroughly consolidated and compacted by ramming with suitable tools.

After the pipes have been covered with two feet of filling as specified, the remainder of the trench may be filled by hand, team or machinery. No large stones shall be allowed to be placed in the trench.

11.0 Coating Pipes: All galvanized pipes will have a heavy coating of hot coal tar or pitch applied before being jointed.

12.0 Joints: All vitrified tile drain pipes are to be laid from lower end up and the contractor will see that each length of pipe is clean before being laid. A gasket of hemp or jute of sufficient size will be inserted between the hub and spigot and properly rammed so that a space 1" in depth shall remain for cement mortar, to be inserted. The space between the spigot and hub shall be completely filled with mortar thoroughly pressed in all around and very promptly sealed to secure a tight joint. The mortar shall be applied with a rubber mitten and rammed or compacted with a wooden caulking tool. Joints shall be finished all around with a neat level. The interior of each pipe joint shall be scraped clean of all projecting material.

13.0 Payments: Payments will be made at the time and in the manner following:

The Contractor shall be entitled to eighty per centum (80%) of the value of the finished work at the end of every month after its commencement on the certified estimate of the engineer, approved by the Commissioner.

All the permanent equipment to be installed in accordance with the plans and specifications approved and forming part of this contract is to be
paid for on an eighty per centum (80%) basis when laid down on the property on the certificate of the engineer.

The remainder of the amount of the contract price with the exception of any deductions required to be made in accordance with this contract, shall, on the completion of the work, be paid to the Contractor, on the certificate of the Engineer, approved by the Commissioner, that the work has been satisfactorily completed in accordance with the terms of the contract.

14.0 In the event of solid rock being encountered in any of the excavations the same will be paid for on a cost basis plus fifteen per centum (15%).

15.0 The works specified herein are to be completed ready for use within a period of ninety (90) days of the signing of the contract.

Sirs-

In accordance with your instructions I visited the work being undertaken under contract to Mr. John Towers at the Onion Lake Indian Residential School on the 27th and 28th instants and beg to report as follows:

Sewerage Disposal Plant:

Good progress has been made on the sewerage system, the trench having been excavated and a 6" drain pipe laid for some 100' above and 90' below the septic tank. The septic tank is well advanced, concrete for the floor and some 3 to 4 feet of wall having been poured. Excellent sand and gravel has been found for this work at a distance of some three miles from it.

The extension of the sewerage disposal line which was recommended in our letter of the 26th instant was investigated and it was found that the proposed extension was desirable for the following reasons:

(1) It places the disposal beds at a more suitable and desirable distance from the school buildings.

(2) The extension places the beds on an area more suited topographically for efficient distribution.

In addition to the cost mentioned in our letter of the 26th instant there will also be a small extra for the construction of a concrete chamber at the point where the boiler room sewer line intersects the septic tank line.

Excavation for the boiler room sewer line revealed the fact that the outlet elevation at the concrete wall of the building was 11 feet below the ground level. This is considerably deeper than originally estimated and entails a deeper trench, which will be partly in solid rock. Arrangements were therefore made with the contractor to take out the difference between estimated depth and actual depth required on a cost plus 15% basis. When the outlet pipe at this point was uncovered it was also found to be obstructed with concrete and debris. An examination of the sump in the boiler room revealed further obstruction which should be cleared out by the contractor for the building. The possibility of obstruction of this pipe within the building indicated the necessity of an inspection chamber at a point outside the building, as shown in red on attached plan. An inspection chamber at this point will enable the plant engineer to determine whether any future obstructions lie within or without the building.

On the sewerage line which takes care of the toilet, baths, etc., a similar inspection chamber should be constructed. On this line obstructions are even more likely to occur than on the line from the boiler room and laundry due to the open flush type of toilets installed for the children and the tendency to dispose of undesirable refuse through the toilets. The necessity of this inspection chamber was so apparent that instructions were left with the contractor to install same on...
the cost plus 15% basis. As only some 2 cubic yards of concrete are required for each chamber and a simple wooden cover will be quite sufficient, the added expense will not be a very serious matter.

Water Supply:

An inspection of the trenches excavated for the sewerage disposal plant revealed the fact that frost penetrated the ground to a depth of 9 feet. In preparing the original cost estimates it was presumed that 8 feet of cover would be sufficient protection for this line. This depth of cover was based upon the assumption that some protection would be afforded by the winter snowfall. It is now realised that this cannot be depended upon in this locality as it is being experienced that in some years only a very light snowfall is received. In view of this information and the serious consequences which would result from a frozen water supply main, it was decided to place this main approximately 1 foot deeper than was originally estimated. An adjustment will be made with the contractor for the added depth.

Fire Protection Plant:

In Mr. Goodchild's original report he stressed the desirability for an adequate system of fire protection, particularly so in view of the value of the building and its equipment. It was considered that provision should be made for at least four streams of 80 gallons per minute each at a pressure of 50 pounds playing simultaneously. From an examination of the fire fighting equipment which has been installed, I do not think it would be possible to use the full capacity of the big fire pump directly into this system. My reason for this statement is that it is most unlikely that a fire would break out on two or more floors at the same time and to endeavor to concentrate the full discharge through the 2½" or even the 2" fire appliances on the various floors of the building would be dangerous to the whole system.

I therefore recommend that provision be made for installing at the discharge end of the pump a 3" piece with valve and short length of 5" pipe to the reservoir. This will permit operator to adjust his pressure on the discharge line and return balance of the flow to the reservoir.

The present location of the fire fighting pump house is far too close to the main building and as it is merely a frame structure, it might easily be endangered by a fire in the main building and rendered useless for the purpose for which it was installed. I therefore propose changing the location of the reservoir and pump house and placing them some 40 feet to the east of the main building, as shown on attached amended plan of the layout.

It is also considered desirable that a length of some 150 feet of 2½" fire hose be on hand at the pump house for immediate use. With a direct service from the pump an incipient fire in or around the buildings could be very effectively dealt with. The additional cost for extra equipment in this case is being obtained, and will consist of:

- 1 hose hanger
- 150' - 2½" canvas hose
- 1 - 5' 3"pm piece
- 1 - 5" value

In order to utilize all of the storage water in case of fire a slight change has been found desirable in the plan of the...
reservoir. This entails provision for a 2-foot sump for the 5-inch suction line as shown on the attached blue-print of the changes recommended in this report.

Rain-water Tank:

The position of the rain-water tank originally shown on the west side of the building will now be constructed on the east side and will adjoin the fire protection reservoir. This change will entail no additional cost and was necessitated by the fact that the outlet point provided by the contractors to connect with the rain-water tank was presumed to be on the other side of the building.

Remark:

It is rather unfortunate that our engineer was not provided with a plan of the building at the time the original survey was made. Had he been furnished with a plan of the general layout, showing the position of fire protection pipelines, sewer outlet points and elevations, much time and a great deal of the changes now found necessary could have been avoided.

I am attaching a blue-print of the changes recommended in this report.
