Sir,

I wired you on the 14th instant in regard to some proposed changes which are required in connection with the work of the water supply and sewage disposal system at the Onion Lake Catholic Indian Residential School.

Mr. John Towers, the contractor, made a special visit to Calgary on the 14th instant, as he was greatly worried when he found the conditions which existed in connection with the outlet elevation for the rain-water system. As I pointed out to you in my wire, the contractor for the building placed the outlet for the rain-water system some 3.1' lower than the downward outlet pipe. It is therefore impossible to connect the two systems. The solution of the problem was outlined to you in my telegram and this method of dealing with the overflow from the roof will be more clearly brought to your attention by a perusal of the attached blue-print, whereon we have shown the proposed changes. Mr. Towers, who realized the importance of taking some immediate action in order to safeguard the department's interests, at once instructed his men to begin to clear the trench of the 6" service water supply line so that the overflow from the rain-water reservoir could be taken to a suitable point near the spring and the line carried in the same trench. It is considered that a 4" vitrified tile pipe some 500' in length will be required and in order to save expense and not hold up the contractor, instructions have been issued for this work to be undertaken. It is hoped that our action in this regard, which appears to us to be the only alternative in a very unsatisfactory situation, will meet with the support of the Indian Department.

Mr. Towers advised us that on July 5th last they experienced an exceptionally heavy rainfall lasting over four hours—in fact, practically a cloud-burst. This downpour flooded the boiler-house and caused a great deal of inconvenience generally. Fortunately, however, by getting his men to work late that night, he was able to relieve the situation by sawing a hole through the wall of the boiler-house and connecting with the sewer line, which had already been constructed. He also reported that the roof of the building caused considerable trouble and inconvenience due to leakage.

We are advised that it is the intention of the Indian Department to install a small steam heater and tank in the boiler-house to be used in connection with the laundry. This has not yet been installed and we should be glad to be informed as to whether or not it is the intention to install this plant, as there is no method at present by which the soft water from the rain-water tank can be heated. It could, however, be connected with such a heating plant and thereby render a double service.

The Director,
Water Power & Reclamation,
Department of the Interior,
OTTAWA.
The work generally is progressing satisfactorily and the septic tank is to be in use in the very near future, Mr. Towers wishing to give the concrete walls and floor a few more days to set before connecting up with the building.

In order to save expense, we instructed the contractor on the 14th instant to include in his earload of equipment being shipped from Winnipeg on Wednesday, the 18th, the additional items of fire fighting equipment which were referred to you in my letter dated the 7th instant. We trust this action will duly receive your approval.

Your obedient servant,

(sgd) J.S.Tempest

Dear Sir;

Calling to your attention the matters discussed by Mr. Ferrier at the time of his inspection of the R. C. Residential School here, I take the liberty of enumerating them in what to us seems the order of their importance, although their proper order is hard to determine, as we consider the following additions to the establishment all necessary.

Foremost possibly in importance, is the talked of storage quarters for the food supply. We have nothing in the way of frost-proof storage for the vegetables etc., which form an important part of our food.

An additional root cellar is possible to construct quickly, but is not accessible during cold weather, and the scheme outlined by Mr. Ferrier seems to be the logical solution of this important feature, consequently, we ask for its construction.

The matter of the cement floors seems next in importance, not only as a matter of economy to the Dept., by making the floors give much longer service, or the very considerable difference in the amount of labor required to keep them in the condition necessary to a clean house, but the matter of the health of the entire student body may easily be affected by dusty, crumbly cement floors during the long winter months when so much time must be spent by all the occupants indoors.

We ask, therefor, that this matter be given due consideration.

Next, the water supply to the stable. This, I will submit, is a reasonable addition to the water supply which the Dept. is installing at the present time.

The stable contains a water trough for the stock, and the pipes extend outside of the stable walls, so that the trench from the main building to the stable, with the connecting pipe line is all that is required to complete the installation.

Dear Sir;

A very unfortunate situation has developed here in connection with our sewerage system. A kitchen drain, which was found stopped up, upon being cleaned disclosed the fact that the main sewer drain has parted, evidently from settling, and that sewage water from the kitchens, wash basins etc., is being deposited under the floors of the basement rooms, between the foundation walls, and is not being carried outside of the building at all.

Acting on the report of our engineer here, we took the matter up with the contractors in Winnipeg, and they have a man on the job here now, who is not, however a plumber, and is simply wired in his report to the contractor, and is awaiting instructions.

The excavation for parts of this building was made too deep, and filled in again. This filled dirt has settled, leaving portions of the floor unsupported underneath, and the boilers are endangered as well. Water from recent rain storms has washed completely under the building, from which fact you may judge of the condition underneath.

This sewer repair, if left to the devices of an unscrupulous plumber, might be made utterly futile by simply joining the ends of the broken pipe together with an additional length, thus forcing the sewerage out through its proper outlet, but forming a sump in the sunken pipe which would be a constant source of trouble and expense, as well as a menace to the health of all occupants of the building. This sort of a repair, even under the adverse conditions prevailing here, could not be made successfully while the job of putting it back in the position specified by your architect would undoubtedly cost several times that.

Where the responsibility for this condition will rest, we may not judge. Neither are we in any position to insist on immediate action, which you will see is vitally necessary, as the children are now coming in, and we are without any sewer at all.

May we ask, therefore, that you will see that we get action on this?

May we suggest, also, that the matter requires the presence of an inspector with authority to see that the repair is properly made.

With the latter request comes the thought that a member of our staff would be personally interested in the matter, and could act in that capacity for the Dep't, more economically than any other, so far as this matter for all time, and our engineer, knowing of these things, would seem to us to be the logical person for that job. May we therefor, suggest his appointment for this sewer matter? Would you care for a detailed report from him as to the condition of the building generally?

Very Respectfully,

Rev. L. Balter, O. M. I.
Principle.

Progress Report for July, 1928, Onion Lake (R.C.) Residential School.

Sewage Disposal System.

Sewer Lines.

Beller Room Sewer.— Completed from manhole at building to Manhole "A", trench back-filled and line in working order.

Main Sewer.— Completed from manhole at building to septic tank and from septic tank to manhole "A", trench back-filled and line in working order.

Sewer from Manhole "A" to Manhole at Disposal Beds.— Trench dug but line not completed.

Piping for this line not yet delivered.

Disposal Beds.

Trenches completed.

Manholes.

Manholes (four) all completed, connected with pipelines, and all in working order.

Manholes at the building not yet backfilled.

When system is in working order and thoroughly tested, these manholes will be covered over.

Septic Tank.

With the exception of the manholes this structure is completed and in running order.

In place of wooden walls for these manholes the writer recommends four-inch concrete walls with plank covers.

This will ensure a permanent wall and avoid the danger of rotting woodwork with the consequent danger of dirt and debris falling into the tank and impairing its efficiency.

It would also make for greater safety.

The contractor assured the writer that the extra cost would be practically nil.

It is recommended that this work be ordered done as suggested.

Water Supply System.

Pipe line to Spring from Reservoir.— Trench dug and supply pipe laid.

The 4" vitrified tile overflow pipe back to the spring has not yet been delivered so it is not laid nor the trench backfilled.
Excavation for tank completed. Tank to be completed first, then dam.

Reservoirs at School.

Excavation about 40% completed.

The above details show all the work done to date.

A considerable amount of rock has been encountered and, as has been already emphasized, circumstances and contingencies have arisen which have caused changes in design and arrangement and layout and these have somewhat delayed operations.

On the whole, however, excellent progress has been made, and the school authorities are highly pleased with the progress made and the obvious quality of the work done.

Another month will see the job practically completed barring accidents or any serious and unforeseen obstacles to the proper completion of the work.

Recommendations.

1. The writer is of the opinion that the water in the rain-water tank should be made available for use in case of fire or for the domestic uses of the school. This can be done very simply by placing a connecting pipe - say 4" in the wall between the two tanks, at the bottom of the rain-water tank.

This should, of course, have a valve, spindle, and wheel to control the flow, the latter carried up through the roof of the tank into the pumphouse.

2. The writer is also of the opinion that means (a valve, spindle and wheel, the latter properly braced) of draining the pool above the dam at the spring should be made available, so that work inside the tank may be possible, if such be at any time necessary.

Dear Sirs,

I received word from Brown & Hudson Contractors for the erection of the R C Indian Residential School at Onion Lake Aug 13 saying that the contract was completed except some minor items, so on the strength of that information and waiting a couple of weeks I proceeded to Onion Lake Sept 1st. I found on arrival that there had been practically nothing done by them since I had visited the school July 8th.

The sub-contractors were trying to make arrangements with men in the locality to do the work but up to the present time they have failed to get any one to do the work.

They told me in their letter that they took the matter up with Mr Gurney Orr when he was in Kenora and he suggested that I issue the final estimate and hold what I considered was enough to cover the work which is incomplete, but seeing that at the present it is so hard to get action from them now it would be more so if they received what was coming to them except the amount covering the work to be done, but if you wish it done that way I will make arrangements to have the estimate issued.

They wrote me about trying to have it arranged to cancel the insurance on the building and under the circumstances I should judge that as the mission have occupied the school that Brown and Hudson should be relieved of carrying the insurance, and I would ask your opinion re same.

They are also asking for an extra of $5250.00 as they claim that when they figured on the school they understood that it was to be erected in Onion Lake alongside of the old one, and in my opinion I consider if that was the case it should be the other way as the old school is over six miles further away from the railway than where it is now located, and they told me that they were given to understand that the distance from the railway to the school was 35 miles and I took the trouble to get the mileage registered on the truck they hauled their material with which gave it a little less than 30 miles to the present site and over 36 miles to where the old school was located, so if there was any adjustment to be made it would be in favor of the Department of Indian Affairs instead of to Brown and Hudson.

There were several items I wished to take up with Dr Scott when he was in Regina and asked Mr W M Graham to arrange for an interview and he promised he would when Mr Scott was here but for some reason he never phoned to let me know but perhaps they were too busy while they were here.

I am figuring out some adjustments of several changes in the layout which were requested by the mission, and I think the reductions will more than cover the extras apart from the recreation...
I am herewith enclosing some estimates which were sent to me here and asked me to forward same to you. One is for staining and varnishing the Chapel Pews, the other is for painting the cement floors and which they claim was taken up with Mr Ferrier when he was at Onion Lake.

With regard to the matter of payments to the contractor, I wish to point out that only one cheque (i.e., for $1,776.70) had been received by Mr. Towers up to this morning, and he informed me that unless he very soon received a substantial sum he would be obliged to close down the work.

Further comment on my part is unnecessary.

Regarding the matter of extra valves and stems for tanks as per our telegrams I wish to say that prices of $25.00 each were based on 3" valves, not 4" and 6" as per your wire of today's date.

It is considered that a 3" valve at the dam at spring is amply sufficient and as the depth of the soft water tank is 4 feet less than that of the main reservoir a valve of 3", or at most, 4", is large enough at this point.

Were the two reservoirs of the same depth, the capacity of the valve orifice would need to more closely approximate the capacity of the pump.

The contractor has a 3" valve and spindle on the job, and has left a hole in the dam to take it if it is decided to place it.

The writer would urge that he be so instructed, as it is his opinion and also that of Mr. Tower's, that a 3" valve is amply sufficient at that point and it can be done for $25.00.

The contractor would probably install a 4" valve at the reservoir for $35.00, and the writer thinks it most desirable that a connection be established between the two tanks, since they have been built side by side.

A progress report will be prepared and forwarded as soon as possible.

In reference to the installation of a 3" valve for emptying the small reservoir created by the dam, should occasion arise. It is considered that this is very desirable as it will undoubtedly be necessary, for various reasons, to be able to empty the reservoir from time to time.

In regard to connecting the spring water reservoir with the rainwater reservoir, it is not considered that this is necessary or desirable and the additional expense is therefore not recommended.

Mr. Jennings reports that no provision was made in the original tender for painting buildings and has instructed Mr. Towers to submit an estimate of cost for this work. It is considered that two coats of a brick red with dark olive trimmings would be suitable for the buildings. It has been found necessary to enlarge the pump-house at the reservoir near the building. This is due chiefly to the fact that two large water tanks for cooling purposes had to be installed near the 25 h.p. engine. These large tanks necessitate a different type of roof and the contractor has therefore been instructed to enlarge the building to provide sufficient accommodation for the tanks and a stove for heating purposes and will be paid the difference between the original estimate and the actual cost of the addition plus 15%.

The contractor has been somewhat concerned about the installation of the 25 h.p. engine, particularly so as the method of connection shown in the drawing submitted cannot be followed out on the ground due to the presence of a large muffler on the engine which is not shown on the drawing, and prevents the drive being taken off as shown on the plans. From Mr. Jennings's verbal report regarding his visit, it would appear that considerable improvement could be made to the condition at the dam by installing a few drain pipes with open joints covered with loose gravel. These are considered necessary in order to collect the water and lead it into the filter bed adjoining the spillway and pump house. In this connection, I may say that the spring water supply at this point needed a great deal more work to insure the collection of the various small seepages than was originally contemplated; in fact, Mr. Towers opened up numerous little channels by hand digging and collected these various little streams,—thereby greatly improving the supply. It is now considered that by installing the drain pipes in the manner indicated and covering them with brush and earth, the supply will be preserved and the "sink" eliminated. In order to compensate the contractor for the work already done in this connection and also for the additional work contemplated, I would recommend that an expenditure of $25.00 be approved. The work of covering up with brush and earth to afford protection against frost will be done by the engineer and directions have already been given him in this regard.

Mr. Jennings has further advised me that he considers a further expenditure at the distribution beds from the septic tank would greatly improve conditions at this point. The distribution channels, which have been constructed in accordance with the plan, are working satisfactorily, but by cutting down the ends of the channels to ground level and extending these in one or two places a very much better distribution would be made. As the cost of doing this work is estimated by the contractor at $10.00, I would recommend that he be instructed to carry out same. Mr. Jennings has drawn my attention to the unsatisfactory delivery of material which the contractor has experienced. Various items of plant and machinery have been delivered with parts missing or not in accordance with the original orders. This has caused considerable delay in erection and has been costly to the contractor. The pumphouse and engine were not assembled at the factory prior to shipment and in both cases, pulleys required changing and other minor parts were in many instances missing.

I would like to mention at this time the fact that the contractor has on many occasions been of great assistance to the staff at the school. During the month of July, when the building was flooded, his men worked at night to help relieve the condition. At other periods, when furniture and equipment was being delivered, his men helped to carry same into the building in order that it might not be damaged by rain and storm. During Mr. Jennings's visit he found the contractor's men were being used for operating the steam plant for heating the school owing to the fact that the caretaker was indisposed. These are only some of the many ways in which the contractor has been of great assistance to the staff at the school and on no occasion has he made any charge for these services. The job on the whole has been a difficult one owing to the fact that the conditions found at the building in regard to outlet pipes, etc., were not in accordance with the drawings submitted. Furthermore, owing to the rainy season and the bad state of the roads between Lloydminster and the school, additional cost of freighting has been unavoidable.

Sir:

Report on the Installation of the Water Supply and Sewage Disposal Systems at Onion Lake (R.C.) Residential School

General Remarks:

The installation above referred to is now complete and the plant installed is in good condition and in operation.

The contractor, Mr. Towers, had the pumps put into operation for inspection purposes and the writer found them to work smoothly and efficiently.

The construction work and the installation of the machinery has been done in a workmanlike manner, it has a good appearance and, in the writer's opinion, with proper handling and care, will give excellent satisfaction and be as permanent as such things can be.

Works at Springs:

The works here can do, and are doing, the work required efficiently and well; and the water supply is more than sufficient to supply the demands of an institution several times larger than the one which it is intended to serve.

Upper Tanks and Pump House:

The changes in design have all been carried out, and everything in connection with these works is in good order.

The pump was operated, the fire hose was connected and a stream thrown over the school building, demonstrating the value and importance of this addition to the fire fighting equipment.

Recommendations:

In connection with the equipment of the 25 H.P. engine, a very serious omission was made. This engine is so cumbersome and the fly-wheels so heavy, that it is quite impossible for one man to start the engine and, as it is now equipped, it takes two strong men from twenty minutes to one half hour or more to start the engine.

An air starter must be installed here; otherwise, the plant for fire fighting purposes would be quite useless.

The writer is informed that such an apparatus, suitable for the starting of this engine, can be purchased for approxi-

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6325, file 659-5, part 3)

PUBLIC ARCHIVES
ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES
CANADA
mately one hundred and fifty dollars; that it can be very easily installed and connected, and that it is capable of starting this engine in thirty seconds or so.

It will be obvious that this is a very necessary equipment. It is suggested that this starter be purchased from the Fairbanks-Morse people and installed under their supervision, as this is considered the only safe and satisfactory way of having this installation done, since Mr. Towers will not be here when it arrives.

As a further protection of a valuable barn and outbuildings, and to enable the west side of the school building to be reached in case of fire, it is recommended that another three hundred (300') feet of 2" fire hose, with couplings, be sent to the school. It is considered that this protection is necessary.

In the matter of additional protection against fire inside the school building and barn and pumphouses, it is urged and recommended that fourteen (14) more soda-acid fire extinguishers be purchased for placement in the corridors in the main building and in the barn and in each pumphouse.

For the quenching of an incipient blaze, these apparatuses are handy, efficient and inexpensive, and their presence here might easily save the school from destruction or check a fire until the fire hose could be brought into play.

With the improvements as suggested, the writer is of the opinion that the fire protection afforded would be as complete as it can reasonably be made.

Water Supply in Building:

The pressure tanks, small typhoon pump, motor with automatic control, as well as the automatic supply for soft water, are all connected up, in working order, and in operation. The systems are in operation and are efficient.

The writer saw the Diaphragm Regulator in operation, also the automatic water system, which is directly connected with the soft water tank, and in each case the operation was smooth, quiet and efficient.

Sewage Disposal System:

Since the writer's last visit on the first of the month, the water supply system has been put into operation, and the septic tank used for the first time.

This system is functioning very satisfactorily, and will easily take care of the work for which it was designed.

The disposal beds are caring for the effluent from the tank and there is as yet no offensive odour therefrom.

The soil here is very nearly pure sand and this is, of course, a very satisfactory condition.
Concluding Remarks:

About the middle of the present month an expert in electrical equipment and pumping machinery from the Fairbanks-Morse firm at Winnipeg visited the school.

This gentleman was of considerable assistance to Mr. Towers, who was at that time getting his equipment hooked up and ready to operate.

The writer has been informed that this gentleman complimented Mr. Towers and his chief mechanic upon the excellent work and careful installation which had been accomplished. He also stated that everything was satisfactory and in first class working order.

As it has not been possible for this branch to have an engineer resident on the job this comment by an outside competent judge is very gratifying, and the writer would suggest that Mr. Towers be commended for the conscientious and thorough manner in which he and his staff have carried out the work entrusted to them.

INSPECTION REPORT ON SCHOOLS ONION LAKE AGENCY.

Dear Mr. Graham,

ONION LAKE R. G. RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL.

I visited this school on three occasions during my stay at Onion Lake. All the details in connection with the construction of this school had not been completed. The electric lighting plant was installed at the time of my visit and the water system was also completed. It appears that there has been a great deal of difficulty experienced in getting the contractors to complete their work. I examined the plumbing system, the heating and lighting plant, and the water in connection with these appears to have been well done. There appears to have been no provision made for a chimney for the laundry and bake oven. They require a stove in the laundry for the purpose of heating irons. The laundry floor has not sufficient fall to carry off the surplus water. As a matter of fact, the fall appears to be away from the drain instead of to it. This is a detail that was pointed out by the Sisters and is not being mentioned here with a view to fault finding.

The fire fighting equipment consists of 2 sets of hose on each floor attached to the water supply system. This equipment, being new, is in first class condition. I noted that there were no fire extinguishers and would point out that all our residential schools, in addition to the hose, we have 2 fire extinguishers on each floor. Access to the fire escapes is obtained through rooms occupied by members of the staff.

The school has been very nicely equipped with new furniture. The Rev. Father Balter O.F.M., has been chosen as Principal. Mr. Balduz is the Farming Instructor and Mr. Rose is Engineer. There are 6 Sisters of Charity, 3 of whom are teachers. The Sister Superior is the business manager of the institution and appears to exercise supervision over the outside operations as the present Principal is not a practical man being more of a student.

FARMING.

This year they had their first crop. 30 acres of wheat produced 575 bushels; 45 acres of oats yielded 3300 bushels. Their garden produced 400 bushels of potatoes, not sufficient for their requirements. The wheat was a good quality of Garnet and will make excellent seed. They will realize a good price for this.

Their stock consists of 18 cattle, including 8 milking cows, 7 horses, 16 pigs and 75 hens. Mr. Balduz appears to be a good farmer and a careful man with stock.

I was very unfavorably impressed with Rose, the Engineer. He had a great deal of fault to find with the plant which he is expected to operate and has succeeded in getting the Principal and the Sister Superior very much dissatisfied. He found fault with the plumbing, the boilers, the electric lighting plant and the water supply system. Even the engine wasn't properly constructed. Everything was wrong. I was presented by the...
I was presented by the Principal with a typewritten list of all the imperfections in connection with this plant and came to the conclusion, after examining the plant, that Mr. Rose was making a big noise to hide his own incompetence. This man is a trouble maker pure and simple, in my opinion, and I think the best class of man to have associated in any way with an institution of this kind. The outside dwelling for the Farming Instructor, as well as the poultry house and implement shed, were nearing completion at the time of my visit.

There are 92 pupils enrolled, 50 boys and 43 girls. The children looked well nourished. There were a few cases of whooping cough and 2 children were sent to the hospital while I was there suffering typhoid symptoms.

This being the first summer that this school has been occupied and as work has been under construction during the whole period, very little has been done towards beautifying the grounds, but as soon as the construction work and buildings are completed, the premises can be put in shape.

The foregoing report is respectfully submitted.

W. Murison,
Inspector of Indian Agencies.
Commissioners Office, Sask.
Nov. 29th, 1928.

Dear Mr. Scott,

You will note what Mr. Grewil, the Engineer at the Onion Lake C. of E. School asks for in the way of hose for fire protection. This might be authorized. You will also note what the Inspector says regarding the completion of the contract at the new R.C. Indian Residential School. He states that no provision was made for chimneys in the laundry and bake-oven. This may or may not have been an oversight, as they may have had some other scheme in view when the plans were drawn. He also complains about the manner in which the laundry floor has been built. I do not know whether this was in accordance with the details of the plans or not. Mr. Hamilton has gone to this school to make a final report and the Department will then be in a position to know just how the matter stands. One matter, however, I think should not escape the attention of the Department and that is that the Inspector says he was not impressed with the Engineer. I do not know whether this man has the proper qualifications or not, but if he has not he should be replaced. It is absolutely wrong to have an incompetent man handling a plant of this kind, as he can do more damage in a few months that we should expect to occur in ten years. I would ask the Department to look carefully into this man's qualifications. The Inspector remarks that he has a great deal to say. I found this to be the case when I was at this school.

Yours very truly,

W. M. Graham,
Indian Commissioner.

Dear Mr. Scott,

You will remember that at the time you visited the new R.C. School here, the Sisters spoke to you about a mail delivery for them, as they are situated about six miles from the nearest postoffice. You then told me to write and remind you of this after you returned to Ottawa. Early in September I mentioned to the Rev. Father Balter, the Principal at the School, that I would write you on the matter, and he then asked me not to trouble you about it, as he had the matter well in hand and that the school was going to have a mail delivery. However, a few days ago he informed me that his negotiations had fallen through, and asked me to write you requesting that you use your influence to obtain this concession for the school.

Father Balter also handed me a copy of an agreement (enclosed) which he had obtained from Mr. Taylor, the Onion Lake mail carrier, offering to collect and deliver the mail at the school for the sum of $100 annually. The whole thing is this - Taylor would have to go about two miles out of his regular route, four times a week, to pick up or drop a bag at the school; and he offers to do this for $100 per year.

With kind regards to Mrs. Scott and yourself, in which Mrs. Turner joins.

Dear Sirs,

Having taken the matter up several times with Brown & Hudson re completing the contract of the Roman Catholic Indian Residential School at Onion Lake, it seems almost impossible to get them to take any action in getting the matter cleaned up, so when I received your request through Mr W M Graham I went up to Onion Lake Friday Nov 30th arriving at the School Monday Dec 3rd. I went over the building and made a thorough inspection and find the conditions as follows.

The heating plant is not completed and in its present condition is not giving satisfaction. There is one boiler out of commission as there seems to be trouble with the wet return, they claim that when they put up steam to about one pound the water leaves the boiler and will not come back till the pressure goes down, the matter has been taken up with Brown & Hudson and the Sub Contractor several times but they do not seem to want to do anything, so I asked the Engineer at the School if he could put the plant in working order, and he assured me that he could so I have notified the Contractors that unless the repairs are completed within thirty days that the changes would be made and the expense would be charged against the contract.

In the final estimate I have allowed $450.00 of a hold back till the work is made satisfactory. There is some cementwork & other adjustments which were taken up with Mr Brown and he made a deal with Mr Rose the Engineer at the school to do the work for $55.00 &
that amount is also held back from final estimate, and the both amounts as mentioned above to be paid over as soon as the work has been done to the satisfaction of the Principal of the School.

You will find herewith enclosed the Final Estimates & also the Final Certificate which I hope you will find in order.

When I was at the School the Sister Superior took the matter up with me about a chimney for the laundry and bakery as you will notice by the plans that there is a room between the bakery and the kitchen which is a store room and at the present time they put a pipe through the partition and into the store room vent flue and in so doing it makes the storeroom too warm and no way to ventilate it.

They also require a stove in the laundry for heating the irons for ironing the laundry. I went into the matter while there & in case you decided to have one built it could be erected in the laundry room and extend up on the outside wall of the chapel which would require about 35 feet of chimney. I took the matter up with a bricklayer at Lloydminster to submit a price for the above and as soon as I receive it I will forward it for your consideration, it is greatly needed from what I saw when there last week, the one chimney would suit for both the laundry and the bakery as the pipe could cross the corridor to the laundry which would do away with the heat in the storeroom. awaiting your further commands I beg to remain.

Your obedient servant

Dear Sirs,

You will find herewith enclosed five accounts for material and labor which was used at the Roman Catholic Indian Residential School, Onion Lake.

The material as supplied by G.T. Hunter of Onion Lake, was used in the construction of the floor over the pit which was made to receive the pressure tanks for the water system.

The corrugated fasts as supplied by Bridgman's Hardware of Winnipeg were used in the construction of the doors for the lockers and cupboards which I had erected for the school.

The glass as supplied by A.F. Miller Hardware Co. of Lloydminster was for the glass doors of the cupboards in the class rooms for supplies.

The account of the McDonald Wilson Electric of Winnipeg I authorized the first items namely 2 bracket lights in the chancel of the chapel, which the principal said was necessary, the rest of the wiring was authorized by Mr. Turner, Indian Agent there at the request of the Sister Superior. The material as specified left at the job was at the request of the Principal and the Engineer; the material shipped to the school as specified on page two of this account, I did not know that it was ordered and when I received their account I forwarded a copy to the principal for information & they notified me that the material had not been received by them. I then took the matter up with the firm and they notified me that the material was shipped from Winnipeg Nov 8th and when I was in Lloydminster the beginning of this month I found it there and checked it off by the account.

The account of the Fairbanks Morse Co., the work was done by them since I left the school so I took the account up with me & had it checked over by the Engineer at the school who assured me that the account was O.K. while I was there I found that the switch board that had not been used being replaced by one suitable for the plant I had it shipped back to the Fairbanks Morse Co. at Winnipeg for which there will be a credit for same coming to you.

In making the above explanation is to explain my position in the matter as it seems to be a little out of the regular way of ordering.

You will notice in the final estimate that there is some extras which I did not receive instructions from you to have done but in asking to have the work done the Sister Superior asked to have the deductions as specified in the final estimate to cover the amount of the extras which was not authorized by you.

I hope when you have looked into my explanation as above you will overlook anything you may think was not quite in order and that my action may meet with your approval. I remain

Your obedient servant

This accounts for the $750.00. In addition to that, he had to haul all his camp supplies and the sum of $100 would be a very reasonable estimate for this additional expense. When Mr. Brown went up to the site of the school in September, he found the state of affairs very different from that intimated by Mr. Turner in his letter of April 11th, and very different from that regarding which he had been advised by the man whom he and the Western Steel Products sent up. Mr. Turner's letter is consistent with the school being built at Onion Lake itself and quite inconsistent with its being built on the present site, 8 miles from Onion Lake. It seems to me that Mr. Brown was perfectly justified in assuming that the school was going to be built right at Onion Lake and that he ought to be recompensed for the additional cost to him due to the erection of the school at the present site. He made his estimates on the basis of the school being built at Onion Lake and the Department has received the benefit of that estimate. The Department in paying Mr. Brown the additional expense is not paying twice. May I also stress the point that the contract itself calls for the erection of an Indian Residential School at Onion Lake, not 8 miles from Onion Lake. In view of the circumstances outlined above, there is a very great difference between the two.

1. Balance for verandah extension and stairs to chapel, $301.00.
This item was authorized by Inspector Hamilton and his statement of $86.34 takes into account only the stairs and does not take into account the verandah extension. The item should stand at $301.00 instead of $86.34.

2. Copper for wash tables.
The plans for wash tables in the basement show that they were to be covered with copper but the plans for the wash tables elsewhere do not so specify and there is no mention in the specifications of copper covering. Mr. Brown tells me that he made no account in his tender for copper covering and that the Department would not be paying twice for it, if it were now allowed as an extra, as he says it should be. Mr. Brown received a telegram in March, 1928 from A. F. McKenzie to the effect that Inspector Hamilton had been requested to advise him that all wash tables were to be covered with copper as indicated in the basement plans; accordingly, copper covering was used and should be paid as an extra $200.00.

The site was to be approximately 4 miles from where the present school is located and 33 miles north of the town of Lloydminster, and the Reverend Principal strongly favoured the site.

On April 6, 1927 Graham was requested to arrange for suitable property for the school farm and to obtain a resolution from the band setting aside the land.

On May 10th, 1927 a letter was received from Mr. Graham enclosing a resolution from the band setting aside 640 acres of land to be used for educational purposes.

On May 27th, 1927 Indian Agent Turner was authorized by telegram to arrange for the fencing of the section for the new school and for the breaking of 75 acres, and on August 11th a voucher was received from Mr. Turner for $85.00 to cover the cost of breaking the 75 acres of land for farming.

On June 27th 1928 a voucher was received from Agent Turner and a cheque issued to cover the cost of the fencing.

Nowhere can I find any correspondence mentioning placing the new school opposite the old building.

Sir:

I have to acknowledge your letter, days as above.
This is with reference to a difference of accounts between Messrs P.T. Roberts Ltd., Wholesale Lumber Dealers, of this city, and Messrs Brown & Hudson, contractors for the building of the Onion Lake R.C. School at Onion Lake.

I am directed by your letter to investigate and to advise if the claim of Messrs P.T. Roberts Ltd. is correct.

I have ascertained certain facts by interviewing Mr. Sam Brown of Brown and Hudson, Mr. P.T. Roberts of Messrs P.T. Roberts Ltd., and Mr. James Gibson who is implicated in this matter as the Salesman of Messrs P.T. Roberts Ltd., and who sold the lumber to be used on the work at Onion Lake.

The order for this lumber, mentioned above, was dated as follows, Winnipeg, June 24th, 1927, and is addressed to Messrs P.T. Roberts Ltd. of Winnipeg, for delivery at Lloydminster, Alta., for the prices shown in the order, the order states the terms of payment and is signed "S. Brown."

Mr. Sam Brown also knows that Messrs P.T. Roberts Ltd. shipped the lumber mentioned in the order, some in June, 1927, bulk in July 1927, some in August and September 1927. Mr. Brown also knows that he paid certain monies from time to time for this lumber, so far as I know, it seems strange that Mr. Brown should say he had no dealings with Messrs P.T. Roberts Ltd., and there is good grounds to be doubtful of the validity of his statement. I understand that Mr. James Gibson, as a salesman called at different times on Mr. Brown. In fact Mr. Brown knew who this man was in a business way.

When I interviewed Mr. Sam Brown re this matter he showed me a receipt. I enclose a copy of this receipt herewith, he gave a cheque to Mr. James Gibson, drawn as shown in the copy of this cheque herewith enclosed, and he gets the receipt, which is signed "P.T. Roberts Ltd" per J. Gibson, both the cheque and the receipt have written thereon "In full &c &c." I think Mr. Gibson exceeded his position with the firm he represented when he gave such a receipt, and my conclusion was confirmed when I read the letter from...
from Messrs P.T.Roberts Ltd., dated 20th Dec., 1927, a copy of this letter is enclosed herewith. After reading this I am again convinced that Mr. Sam Brown was well aware that he was dealing with Messrs P.T.Roberts Ltd. Mr. Brown's assumed ignorance, as to Messrs P.T.Roberts Ltd., is only an excuse, and is taken to back up his claim that he "settled in full" with Mr. James Gibson, which claim I feel is on a very doubtful base.

When Mr. James Gibson turned in to Messrs P.T.Roberts Ltd., the cheque he had received from Mr. Sam Brown he endorsed it and Messrs P.T.Roberts Ltd. placed the amount of $160.00 to the credit of Mr. Sam Brown's account, and notified Mr. Sam Brown that this was "not in full" settlement of his account (see letter 20 Dec., 1927). After this incident Messrs P.T.Roberts Ltd. that they move to protect themselves and they then addressed Mr. W.A. Hamilton, the Building Inspector of construction. This action then placed Mr. Brown in the position that he would have to meet Messrs P.T.Roberts Ltd. to get his "settlement", so called, confirmed. Mr. Brown takes the position that he "does not know Messrs P.T.Roberts Ltd.", which in my opinion is foolish, as the receipt, on which he bases his claim of "settlement in full", is signed "P.T.Roberts Ltd., per J. Gibson", and in order to have this receipt confirmed it is in his interest to meet the lumber people.

I have also found that there were some other difficulties developed by the fact that Mr. W.A. Hamilton would not accept some lumber that was offered for the job, as it was "off grade". Messrs P.T.Roberts Ltd. shipped the grades they received an order for, but they had nothing to do with the grades Mr. Sam Brown ordered, except to ship what was asked, the prices given were for the grades ordered. When the "off grade" was fixed by the Building Inspector, Mr. Brown felt that he must blame someone else, so you can readily understand what he would do.

As a sensible business man, having his own best interests at stake, I told Mr. Brown that he should seek and court a satisfactory settlement with Messrs P.T.Roberts Ltd., and to do this quickly by calling on them and asking what was the trouble. Mr. Brown says he will not meet Messrs P.T.Roberts Ltd. In short he will not proceed to take any steps to adjust differences. Under the circumstances then, I think The Department, taking a proper stand to inform Mr. Brown that they have to insist upon his getting this dispute adjusted and validated without any further delay. Such a request would bring Mr. Brown to the realise that he is really the cause of delay in closing this business up.

1. Mr. Brown placed order with Messrs P.T.Roberts Ltd. and arranged terms of payment with them. Not with Mr. James Gibson.
2. Mr. Brown attempts to make a settlement with Mr. James Gibson, and he is notified that what he did with Mr. Gibson is not a "full settlement" as long ago as the 20 Dec., 1927. In spite of this notice he is still holding off closing the account with the proper principals.
3. He feels hurt because Messrs P.T.Roberts took proper steps to protest
3. Protect their interests by informing the Building Inspector of their difficulties with the contractor. Mr. Brown could and can readily remedy this phase of the business.

4. The trouble about grades of material cannot be placed against the lumber people; they shipped what was ordered and were paid for what they shipped. In fact any claims by Mr. Brown have, so far as I can find out, been adjusted and fixed up; his account indicates that.

5. The balance claimed is indicated in the statement of account as rendered. All payments made by Mr. Brown have been properly credited to him. I think it is up to Mr. Brown to show why he persists in holding up a settlement. The balance claimed is correct so far as I can determine that.

Sir,

I regret having to trouble you further with the particulars of the contract for the new Onion Lake School, but Brown has submitted statements regarding the extra he is asking for change in site, and I would be glad to have your opinion. I beg to quote the following:

"BUILDING AND FURNISHING CAMPS. $1,800.00. If the site had been at Onion Lake near the old school, Mr. Brown could have used certain buildings at Onion Lake belonging to the Hudson's Bay Co., which were available and vacant and convenient to the job. Instead of that he had to erect certain buildings near the job some 6 miles away including a bunk house, a cook house, an office for the Inspector and an office for Mr. Hudson and himself. Mr. Brown did not figure on these buildings in view of the situation which had been disclosed to him at Onion Lake itself so that there is no question of the Department paying twice for this item.

HAULING WATER. $1,400.00. At Onion Lake itself, water was available right on the job and could have been taken out of the well near the old School. You will note that Mr. Turner in his letter of April 11th states that water is right on the job. It would certainly appear that at the time Mr. Turner wrote this letter, he had in mind that the site would be right near the old school at Onion Lake. As a matter of fact, all the water had to be hauled a distance of over three-quarters of a mile uphill, and water was hauled this distance right from the commencement of the job until its completion and wages were paid at the rate of approximately 45¢ per hour for hauling water. Mr. Brown tells me that his estimate of $1,400.00 for this item which would not have been necessary if the site had been at Onion Lake near the old school, is very conservative.

DIFFERENCE IN COSTS OF GRAVEL. $1,200.00. Mr. Turner says in his letter of April 11th, 1929, that he does not think that the gravel haul will be more than a mile. As a matter of fact, Brown had to haul gravel a distance of about 4 miles instead of 1 mile. He had considerable difficulty in finding gravel and had to open up a pit himself. The cost of hauling gravel a distance of a mile would have been about $2.00 per yard for hauling. The government was constructing a barn not far from the school and was paying $1.75 per yard for gravel whereas Mr. Brown estimated this item..."
at $1.00 per yard and did so on the strength of Mr. Long Turner's letter. Mr. Brown had to pay $1.75 per yard for hauling instead of $1.00 as contemplated.

HAULING LUMBER AND CAMP SUPPLIES. Mr. Brown used about 125,000 feet of lumber and it cost him $6.00 per thousand for hauling it from Onion Lake to the site of the school. This accounts for the $750.00. In addition to that, he had to shell all his camp supplies and the sum of $100.00 would be a very reasonable estimate for this additional expense. When Mr. Brown went up to the site of the school in September, he found the state of affairs very different from that intimated by Mr. Turner in his letter of April 11th, and very different from that regarding which he had been advised by the men whom he and the Western Steel Products sent up. Mr. Turner's letter is consistent with the school being built at Onion Lake itself and quite inconsistent with its being built on the present site, 6 miles from Onion Lake. It seems to me that Mr. Brown was perfectly justified in assuming that the school was going to be built right at Onion Lake, and that he ought to be recompensed for the additional cost to him due to the erection of the school at the present site. He made his estimates on the basis of the school being built at Onion Lake and the Department has received the benefit of that estimate. The Department in paying Mr. Brown the additional expense is not paying twice. May I also stress the point that the contract itself calls for the erection of an Indian Residential School at Onion Lake, not 6 miles from Onion Lake. In view of the circumstances outlined above there is a very great difference between the two."

As far as the Department's records show it was never contemplated placing the building at any other site than the one selected. I would appreciate having your views on these statements at your earliest convenience.

Dear Sirs,

In answer to your letter of the 5th which was received today asking information re claims of Brown & Hudson as to change of site of the R.C. Indian Residential School at Onion Lake. I will give you my opinion on the several items in the order as they appear in your letter.

Item #1 Building and furnishing camp. £800.00

In the first place the specifications call for the school to be erected on the Onion Lake Indian Reserve, and that the bidders were supposed to visit the site of the proposed work and ascertain for themselves as to the existing conditions. The buildings referred to as bunk house, cook house, office for the company also office for the inspector did not cost them £500.00 altogether and then they got a fair price for them when they were through with them and in my opinion it would have cost them far more if they had rented buildings.

Item #2 Hauling water. £400.00

There is a lake about 300 yards from where the school site is and a fine spring about 150 yards from the building, and if Mr. Hudson had taken the interest in the work he should have done he could have put up a small gasoline engine and a pump at the spring and could have supplied all the water required for the work and also for drinking purposes. This spring is at present supplying all the water required for the school, and as for Mr. Turner saying that the water was right at the site he was correct, and in all my conversation with Mr. Turner he never mentioned any other site than the one where the school is located, and the water is far better.

Item #3 Difference in cost of gravel. £200.00

All the gravel used in the building did not cost them more than £1.25 per yard as most of it was procured within a mile of the job and when the pits run out they hauled from another pit from which they paid £1.25 per yard for hauling and 20¢ to the Agency. The reason the Government had to pay £1.75 for gravel was on account of most of the teams were out harvesting. Mr. Hudson put their trucks at hauling gravel and they made eight trips per day with each truck from the farthest pit.

Item #4 Hauling lumber and camp supplies.

The price charged for hauling lumber from Onion Lake was £3.00 per thousand, and the amount of lumber they received from Onion Lake was approximately 35,000 feet but the balance of the £8,000 feet of lumber namely about 90,000 feet they saved money on the hauling as the new school is about seven miles closer to the Railway than the old school site, and the above applies to the Camp Supplies.

Referring to the change of Site they never mentioned anything to me about it till about the time the contract should have been completed and in talking with the agent Mr. Turner at Onion Lake...
and also the authorities at the St Anthonies School they told me that they had never considered having the school erected at the old site in Onion Lake.

There are some conditions that existed in the handling of the work in connection with the erection of the school which was anything but good management, and I feel sorry for Mr Brown as any loss which has occurred through the way the work was handled will have to be borne by him, but of course it was his own fault as he should have known the man he was sending there to handle the work.

I hope that the above explanation may be of assistance to you in deciding re the claim referred to, and in reference to the first clause of your letter of regret in having to trouble me in regard to the particulars, I am only too pleased to give you any assistance possible in getting the matter straightened out for I am sure you must be near the end of your patience, and any other information I can give you will be cheerfully given. I beg to remain

Your obedient servant

MEMORANDUM:
The Acting Deputy Minister.

Re Application of Atlas Exploration Company Ltd., for Alexandra and Louise Falls, Hay River, N.W.T.

With reference to your memorandum of April 13th last, tagged on the file asking for a draft reply for the Minister's signature on an application of the Atlas Exploration Company Limited, also tagged for your approval, please covering Alexandra and Louise Falls, Hay River, N.W.T., I beg to submit as follows:

General Description.

These Falls, as is indicated on the attached map, are located upwards of 40 miles from the mouth of Hay river, which enters Great Slave lake some 70 or 80 miles west of the mouth of the Slave river and 250 miles distant by river and lake from Fort Smith. Our engineers made a reconnaissance survey of these Falls in the summer of 1921 and estimated that under ordinary minimum flow conditions an aggregate of 27,000 horse power would be available and upwards of 60,000 horse power for six months at the two sites, in two developments. The engineer reported that the two crops might possibly be combined in one development and this, apparently, is what the present applicant proposes.

Use to be made of Power.

The Company proposes to transmit the power 40 miles to certain lead-zinc deposits located west of Pine Point on Great Slave lake and use it there for the recovery of the metals indicated where probably all the power obtainable will be required.

Other Sources of Power.

The nearest large source of power other than that applied for appears to be that on the Slave river, in the fall between Fitzgerald and Fort Smith upwards of 100 miles distant in a direct line from the mineral deposits. The Slave river sites are very large and would, with the transmission line required, probably involve a much larger outlay than the Hay river sites.

R. A. Gibson, Esq.,
Acting Deputy Minister,
Department of the Interior,
OTTAWA.

Report of N.W.T. Branch.

As the site applied for is in the North West Territories it has been referred to Mr. Finnie and from his memorandum on file, immediately hereunder, it appears that he has no objection to offer to the favourable consideration of the application when the provisions of our Regulations have been fully complied with.

Scenic Considerations.

We have on our file copy of a memorandum by Mr. Harkin, dated June 20th, 1917, suggesting that steps be taken to preserve these Falls from disfigurement and recommending that instructions be issued to reserve the lands in the vicinity from homestead or mining entry. This recommendation was apparently approved by the then Minister, Hon. Dr. Roche, and acted upon by the Land Patents Branch. So far as I am aware no further action in the matter has been taken.

Information Furnished.

The information furnished by the applicant is not sufficient under the Dominion Water Power Regulations to permit the issue of an Interim License for a power development, but it is adequate with the data already secured by our own officers to justify the issue of a Priority Permit. A Priority Permit under our Regulations, as you are aware, does not constitute a definite concession nor does it obligate the Department in any way to subsequently grant such concession, it merely grants the applicant priority in the consideration of his general layout plans for a fixed period and thereby affords him protection for the time he requires to make surveys and plans and prepare the information required by the Department before an Interim License can be considered.

Recommendation.

I beg to recommend, therefore, that the Atlas Exploration Company be advised that the information contained in their application is insufficient for the consideration of the issue of an Interim License for the site, but that the Department is prepared to issue a Priority Permit for the period of one year in order that the applicant may proceed with its surveys and prepare the further information required. A letter along these lines is submitted herewith which, if it meets with your approval, might be forwarded over the Minister's signature.

Respectfully submitted,

SUPPLY OF MATERIAL AND EQUIPMENT -

4.0 The contractor will supply all material and equipment which enter into and form part of the finished structures, and all material required for the construction and maintenance of forms and the like.

4.1 Transport: The contractor will transport all material and equipment from the Railway station to the site of the work. The cost of transport will be included in the contract price for "Material Supplied" and "Equipment Supplied".

4.2 Care of Material: All material must be properly stored and cared for at all times. It will be subject to inspection before being used and if any is found to be damaged or in any way rendered useless or unsuitable it will be condemned and must immediately be removed from the work and replaced by suitable material by the Contractor at his sole expense.

SHOW, ICE AND DEBRIS -

5.0 Snow, ice and Debris and foreign matter must be removed from the work whenever ordered by the Engineer, such removal being at the Contractor's expense.

FORMS -

6.0 Forms, where necessary, will be furnished and built by the Contractor and included in the contract price per cu. yd. of concrete.

6.1 Materials in forms may be used repeatedly but if so used shall be thoroughly cleaned after each time used and before setting up again. Before any concrete is poured against them the moulding surface must be speared with mineral oil or grease, or soap, in order to prevent the concrete from adhering to the forms.
6.2 Forms must be left in place until the concrete has set sufficiently to be safe from damage, either in process of removal, or from lack of support or from any other cause. The method employed in removal of forms must be such as to offer the minimum possibility of damaging the soft concrete; using sift concrete as a fulcrum for prying forms loose is specially forbidden.

REINFORCEMENT -

7.0 The contractor will provide, fabricate and fix in place all reinforcement shown on the drawings or required by reason of the methods of construction adopted by him. He must take whatever precautions are necessary, or are ordered by the Engineer, to maintain such reinforcement in its proper position while pouring concrete and afterward until the concrete is set.

7.1 Material: Unless otherwise shown on the drawing or permitted by the District Engineer all reinforcement will be round steel bars meeting the requirements of the Standard Specifications of the American Society for Testing Materials for "Billet Steel Concrete Re-inforcement Bars (Serial designation A-15)" as adopted 1911 with all subsequent revisions.

7.2 Fabrication: The Contractor will do all work necessary in connection with cutting, bending, erection, tying, splicing and anchoring.

7.3 Bending: Wherever bars are shown on the drawing as bent to any shape, such bars will be bent cold (except anchors) using a suitable tool or appliance for the purpose.

7.4 Maintenance: All reinforcement must be so supported that it cannot be displaced before during or after the operation of pouring the concrete.

CONCRETE -

8.0 Materials, plant, labour, tools and appliances for proportioning, mixing, transporting, placing and finishing concrete will be supplied by the Contractor.

8.1 Materials: All material supplied will be tested and if defective must be immediately moved from the work and made good at the contractor's expense. Rejected material, if not removed within four days, may be destroyed or rendered useless by the Engineer.

8.2 Aggregate: The aggregate for concrete will consist of sound particles of silicious or calcareous rock. The particles must be free from hard adhering films or coatings of deleterious matter, such as clay, salts or vegetable acids.

8.3 Cement: All cement must comply with the requirements of the "Specification for Portland Cement" of the American Society for Testing Materials as adopted September 1st, 1916, and all subsequent amendments or the standards of the Engineering Institute of Canada. Cement may be shipped in bags or barrels at the option of the Contractor.
8.4 Transport and Storage: Cement must be protected from the weather during transport and at all times. It must be stored as directed by the engineer in charge and be subject to inspection at any time. If found defective the whole or such part as the engineer may direct must be immediately removed from the work and replaced with new cement at the contractor's expense.

8.5 Reinforced concrete (which for this purpose is defined as all concrete members in which steel is employed to take certain definite stresses which the concrete itself is incapable of taking) will be mixed in the proportion of one part of cement to two parts of fine aggregate and four parts of coarse aggregate, measured dry. Each bag of cement will be considered as one cubic foot and each barrel as four cubic feet and the volume of aggregate adjusted accordingly.

8.6 Mass concrete (which for this purpose is defined as all concrete members in which all direct stresses are borne by the concrete unaided although steel may be employed for temperature, shrinkage or other reasons) will be mixed in the proportion of one part of cement, two and one half parts fine aggregate and five parts of coarse aggregate. Packages of cement will count for volume as above specified.

8.7 Maximum sizes of aggregate in reinforced work will not exceed one and one half inches in greatest dimension. For mass concrete no particle may be used greater in longest dimension than two tenths (2/10) of the least dimension of the member for which the concrete is intended.

8.8 Consistency: Sufficient water will be used in mixing concrete to give a mixture which will flow (not slide) readily on a plank surface inclined at 25 degrees to the horizontal. For reinforced work, especially in vertical members such as walls, slabs, counterforts and columns, the concrete must be mixed sufficiently fluid to flow readily into corners and angles and about the reinforcing steel and to fill all voids.

8.9 Finish: After removal of forms, the surface will be carefully examined for exposed reinforcement. All holes, open voids, or pockets will be filled with stiff mortar mixed one to one and rammed in hard. The joints will be clipped off neatly flush with the surface. Bolt holes will be carefully cleaned out by jet of water, air or steam under pressure and filled with stiff mortar. The whole surface of all members, except floors, will be painted with neat grout.

9.0 Excavation of Trenches: The trenches in which the pipes are to be laid shall be excavated on the lines shown on the plan. There shall be no bonds or undulations made other than those shown on plan or permitted by the Engineer.

6.1 Materials in forms may be used repeatedly but if so used shall be thoroughly cleaned after each time used and before setting up again. 6.2 Forms must be left in place until the concrete has set sufficiently to be safe from damage, either in process of removal, or from lack of support or from any other cause. The method employed in removal of forms must be such as to offer the minimum possibility of damaging the soft concrete; using sift concrete as a fulcrum for prying forms loose is specially forbidden.

7.0 The contractor will provide, fabricate and fix in place all reinforcement shown on the drawings or required by reason of the methods of construction adopted by him. 7.1 Material: Unless otherwise shown on the drawing or permitted by the District Engineer all reinforcement will be round steel, as meeting the requirements of the Standard Specification of the American Society for Testing Materials for "Billet Steel Concrete Reinforcement Bars (Serial designation A-15)" as adopted 1911 with all subsequent revisions.

7.2 Fabrication: The Contractor will do all work necessary in connection with cutting, bending, erection, tying, splicing and anchoring.

7.3 Bending: Wherever bars are shown on the drawing as bent to any shape, such bars will be bent cold (except anchors) using a suitable tool or appliance for the purpose.

7.4 Maintenance: All reinforcement must be so supported that it cannot be displaced before during or after the operation of pouring the concrete.

8.2 Aggregate: The aggregate for concrete will consist of sound particles of silicious or calcareous rock. The particles must be free from hard adhering films or coatings of deleterious matter, such as clay, salts or vegetable acids.

8.3 Cement: All cement must comply with the requirements of the "Specification for Portland Cement" of the American Society for Testing Materials as adopted September 1st, 1916, and all subsequent amendments, or the Standards of the Engineering Institute of Canada. Cement may be shipped in bags or barrels at the option of the Contractor.
8.4 Transport and Storage: Cement must be protected from the weather during transport and at all times. It must be stored as directed by the engineer in charge and be subject to inspection at any time. If found defective the whole or such part as the engineer may direct must be immediately removed from the work and replaced with new cement at the contractor's expense.

8.5 Reinforced concrete (which for this purpose is defined as all concrete members in which steel is employed, to take certain definite stresses which the concrete itself is incapable of taking) will be mixed in the proportion of one part cement to two parts fine aggregate and four parts of coarse aggregate, measured dry. Each bag of cement will be considered as one cubic foot and each barrel as four cubic feet and the volume of aggregate adjusted accordingly.

8.6 Mass concrete (which for this purpose is defined as all concrete members in which all direct stresses are borne by the concrete unaided although steel may be employed for temperature, shrinkage or other reasons) will be mixed in the proportion of one part of cement, two and one half parts fine aggregate and five parts of coarse aggregate. Packages of cement will count for volume as above specified.

8.7 Maximum sizes of aggregate in reinforced work will not exceed one and one half inches in greatest dimension. For mass concrete no particle may be used greater in longest dimension than two tenths (2/10) of the least dimension of the member for which the concrete is intended.

Dear Sir,

Your favor of April 2nd received and carefully noted.

Re ITEM NO. 1.

The men had to travel back both night and morning, a distance of eight miles by horse and wagon, also carting of all the material caused much delay and extra expense. We could not sell them for money, only succeeded in getting rid of them by trading them for poplar wood at a mere fraction of their value. We realized approximately $100.00 for them in that way, which might be deducted from the $1,800. Otherwise costs are quite reasonable and could not be built under the circumstances for any less.

ITEM NO. 2.

I cannot understand Mr. McLean's remarks on this item. There is only one lake in the vicinity near the school and that is approximately half a mile in a straight line and I presume two hundred and fifty feet below the school site, but the wayround to the lake to overcome the steep descent is three-quarters of a mile. There is a series of small springs approximately 1200 feet from the school and from eighty to a hundred feet below school level. The stream was so small that it required about five minutes to fill a pail. We considered building a reservoir and pumping it up but estimated it would cost more than getting it from the lake. To verify this it must have cost the Department about $3,000.00 to get their water supply from this source. I know the tenders they received were in that neighborhood. We tendered for it ourselves so you see there was no alternative for us but getting the water from the lake.

ITEM NO. 3.

There was no gravel pit known to anybody up there nearer than Onion Lake. We were two weeks discovering the pit where we obtained the gravel which was on private property and as near four miles
as they could measure it with the speedometer on the truck. If they still dispute Item No. 2 and No. 3, the Lake will speak for itself also the gravel pit as both can be seen. (To verify this the Department paid $1.75 for gravel from the same pit for the barn).

ITEM NO. 4.

There was two hundred and fifty-eight thousand feet of lumber in the school; approximately eighty thousand feet was purchased in the vicinity of Onion Lake from different parties but all supplies for camps also other supplies for the school are included in the $550.00.

SUMMARY:

The sum of $200.00 has not been paid for copper coverings ordered but not specified. Deepening machinery room has only been partially allowed. The Department have Mr. Hudson's sworn declaration for the right amount. Extras for electrical work have not been allowed. I think I gave you particulars of this item.

DEDUCTIONS:

Full amount of labor and material have been deducted whereas only labor should be deducted as material was supplied. Correct amount of this item should be one-third of Inspector's figures.

Yours truly,

"S. BROWN"

Dear Mr. Graham:

I beg to direct your attention particularly to conditions with respect to the fire escapes and fire protection equipment at the R.C. Residential School, Onion Lake Agency.

FIRE ESCAPES.

Two very steep iron ladder stairways are provided, one for each wing, with access to same from each floor. These stairways terminate about 6 ft. from the ground and are installed at the front of the building. In the event of a fire at night there is grave danger that serious casualties might take place. When I last visited this school in October 1923 I informed the principal that the Department regulations called for regular fire drill and pointed out the importance of the children being trained in this respect. Upon my recent visit I again took up this question and was informed by the Sister Superior that they were afraid to send the children down the present escapes. They consider them very dangerous. Apart from the danger in connection with the steep descent, there is the necessary jump at the bottom. I pointed out that they might make some temporary arrangement at the bottom of these stairways whereby the children would not have so far to drop to reach the ground, and again impressed upon them the importance of having regular fire drill.

W. M. Graham, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner,

FIRE ESCAPES (CONT'D.)

I would suggest that four pole fire escapes be installed, one for each dormitory, similar to those which were installed at the Edmonton Residential School at a cost of $125.00 each.

FIRE FIGHTING EQUIPMENT.

Since my last visit a separate unit has been provided exclusively for fire protection purposes. This consists of a 25 Horse Power Fairbanks-Morse engine and a force pump which has capacity to deliver water at a pressure of 150 lbs. to the square inch. Only 100 ft. of hose has been provided for this unit. The pump house is located 25 ft. from the building. The building has a 144 ft. frontage, and is 160 ft. from the front to the rear, so it is very easily seen that the length of hose is inadequate.

It appears to me that this equipment would be absolutely useless in its present condition in the event of a fire taking place, for the following reasons:

In the first place, it requires five men to start the engine and one man is required with a pry to keep the belt on the pulleys. I am informed that when the engine was installed and tried out it took the expert and five men 23 minutes to start it. An 8" belt delivers the power from the engine to the pump and is not large enough to work the pump to its full capacity of 150 lbs., and they reduced the valve to 60 lbs. pressure, and when the outfit is in operation it is necessary to have a man with a pry, as I said before, to keep the belt in its place. Either this plant has not been...
been properly installed and thoroughly tested, or it will be necessary to have it equipped with a compressed air starter. It is very evident, I think, that an outfit requiring five men to start the engine is of very little value at an institution of this kind. In the event of a fire starting and the absence of some members of the staff, it would be impossible to operate the outfit, and even when started its usefulness would be considerably curtailed through an inadequate supply of hose.

This plant, I am informed, was installed by the Water, Power & Immigration Co., Calgary, and a man named Goodchild from their Head Office in Calgary passed it.

Dear Mr. Scott:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 13th instant regarding fire protection equipment at the Onion Lake R.C. School, and I note the Department is taking steps to have the Dominion Water Power Branch look into this matter.

With regard to the last paragraph of your letter in reference to the installing of pole fire escapes, I note you state that in using this type of escape accidents have occurred from pupils sliding down the pole before the preceding pupil had reached the bottom or left the pole at the ground, and also that in extremely cold weather in the winter there have been cases where pupils leaving hot dormitories have stuck to the metal pole with serious injury resulting. I recommended pole fire escapes for the reason that the reports I have from our Inspectors, in addition to the impressions which I gained through personal observation on many occasions led me to believe that they were the ideal thing for Indian Schools. I have never known of a case where a child had to put its hands on the pole when sliding down, so that the danger of injury resulting in frosty weather would be negligible. It was only within the last five or six days I watched the children coming down the poles at the Cowessess School. Thirty children came down from the third storey in less than two minutes, and not one child was touching the pole with hands or feet, as they merely hugged it with their legs and arms. There was no confusion at the bottom, and if there had been a case where one child lit on top of another it would not have been very serious. We have ladder escapes at some

Duncan C. Scott, Esq.,
Deputy Supt. General,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
of our schools, and these, in the opinion of the Inspectors and myself, are most dangerous. If a child slips on one of these ladders it is liable to be seriously hurt, and as some of the ladders are almost perpendicular and in some cases even attached right to the wall of the building it is pretty difficult for small children to negotiate them. The open stair type of escape is just about as bad, as the treads on these are not more than six or seven inches wide, and to get a lot of children seven or eight years of age down these steps is almost an impossibility. Then again, on this type of escape it is necessary for the children to hold on to an iron hand rail all the way down so that the danger in cold weather of having the skin peeled off their hands would be much greater than with the pole escapes.

Your officers here have given a good deal of personal consideration to this matter and I think their views should be considered. I should like to see the pole fire escapes installed, as I think they are in every way the most efficient and the safest means of getting the children out of a building in case of fire, but it is, of course, for the Department to decide whether poles or treads shall be used. I may say that the treads cost four or five times as much as the poles, but I am not taking this into consideration in making this report.

Yours very truly,

W. M. Graham,
Indian Commissioner.

As you will observe in the first paragraph on page E of Mr. Thorson's letter, he bases his claim primarily on the information contained on the outer cover of the specifications, that "for all information with reference to the site of the proposed building contractors should refer to Indian Agent, Lang Turner, (Union Lake, Sask.)" and on the letter which Mr. Brown received from Agent Turner in reply to his enquiry, dated the 11th April, 1927, it is stated also that Mr. Brown sent a man to Union Lake to look over the ground and this man was told by some person that the site was to be right beside the old school at Union Lake, and it is intimated that Mr. Brown's tender was based on this information. I beg to inform the Department that Mr. Murison, having just returned from Onion Lake, reports that while at the R.C. School there a man arrived from Winnipeg to install a compressed air starter in connection with the 25 h.p. engine which supplies the power at this institution.
