Dear Mr. Graham:

I beg to report that I visited the Onion Lake Roman Catholic Residential School on the 7th instant and made a general inspection of the buildings.

When visiting the engine room in the main building, I noted that the wiring from the switchboard and dynamos had not been insulated. The wire was simply wound around nails and spikes and hanging loose. When the Fairbanks-Morse Co. representative, Mr. Pedersen arrived the same day, I brought this matter to his attention and he stated that last fall he paid Mr. Rose, who was then the engineer at the school, the sum of $40.00 to do this work and sent the necessary insulators. The Farming Instructor, Mr. Balduc, who was present, produced a box which he said he did not know the contents of, and upon opening it, the insulators and other material was found. Mr. Pedersen said that he would interview Mr. Rose regarding this work. This is a matter that I pointed out to the Principal as one which should be attended to as I do not consider it safe in its present condition.

Sir:-

I beg to enclose herewith a report of an inspection made at the various schools in the Onion Lake agency.

I would draw your attention to the very unsatisfactory condition of the plaster on the inside walls of the R.C. School, and also the paint on the outside. It looks to me as though the work had been very defective and there is criticism coming to the Inspector who was in charge. It seems too bad that in a remote part of the country where it is so difficult to get work done, special care was not taken to see that it was performed in a proper manner. The Department will be called upon now to spend a considerable sum of money to put this building in repair, although it is practically new. I would also draw your attention to the manner in which the Fairbanks-Morse Company installed the new 25 H.P. engine at this school. The purpose of supplying this engine was, I understand, to provide adequate fire protection. I do not know what the Department's arrangements were regarding the installation, but it seems to me most unusual that Mr. Rose, while employed as Engineer at the school, should undertake work of this kind, and be paid twice for his time. I think the Department should look into this matter. We have had trouble in the past with this large engine and it seems to me that our troubles are not ended. It is so important that we should have fully qualified Engineers at these institutions, otherwise we are just smashing, breaking and spending money recklessly in repairs. I think the Department should take immediate steps and call upon the people who agreed to install the engine to see that the wiring is properly done.

Sir:—

With reference to my letters of Dec. 26th. and January 7th., and Department letters of January 2nd. and 13th. last dealing with the matter of fire protection equipment at the Onion Lake R.C. Indian Residential School, the installation of which was placed in the hands of the Dominion Water Power Branch, at Calgary, I may say that although we have been corresponding on this subject for a month we do not appear to get anywhere.

In the first place, the Company handled the work very badly and have sent in connections that will not connect with the standpipe. We have had sketches made of the couplings, and I have been in correspondence with Messrs. Bell & Morris, with whom the Dominion Water Power Branch placed the order, and they apparently cannot understand what is wrong. It seems to me this should have been a simple matter if it had been properly handled. First of all, the people who supplied the hose and couplings should have made careful inquiry from the Dominion Water Power Branch regarding the size of the couplings on the standpipe. Will the Department place the matter in the hands of the Dominion Water Power Branch and let them finish their job. I have had plumbers here who agree with me that the only thing to do is to let the people who undertook the work complete it. The trouble is that the outlet on the hydrant is 3-3/16 inches in diameter and 6 threads to the inch, whereas the hose couplings supplied are 2-3/16 inches diameter and 8 threads to the inch. I have pointed this out to Messrs. Bell and Morris but it does not appear to be understood.

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

It seems—
It seems to me this is the only way to straighten out this unsatisfactory business. We are putting in hose and connections at various points all the time, and never have any difficulty like this.

It will be necessary to supply a new nozzle to fit the hose supplied by Bell and Morris, and the Rev. Principal asks for a half inch outlet, as the present one uses the water too fast.

Your obedient servant,

Inspector Morrison's Report on Schools in the Onion Lake Agency.

R. C. INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL

Dear Mr. Graham:

I visited this school on March 4th, and made a general inspection of the buildings. There were 109 pupils enrolled and 3 non treaty children, about whom there has been considerable correspondence. The Principal is making an effort to have these children taken over by the Province. I found the children neat and clean. They have a well nourished appearance. The school building was scrupulously clean and tidy throughout.

FIRE PROTECTION

Since my last visit pole fire escapes have been installed with access to them from the dormitories. These are in addition to the outside stairways. Regular fire drill is given the children. I had them demonstrate the use of both the stairways and the fire escapes, and noted that they evacuated the school very quickly when they used the pole escapes. The stairways, as I have already pointed out, are very steep, and it was noted that care had to be taken by the children when going down these stairs. There is altogether too long a drop at the bottom and some means should be provided to decrease this. They have to jump about 5 ft. to the ground when they reach the bottom of the stairs, and the children are apt to hurt themselves.

W. M. Graham, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner,
Regina, Sask.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6325, file 659-5, part 4)
R. C. INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL (CONT'D.)

FIRE PROTECTION (CONT'D.)

I found the fire equipment in good condition, and it will be in good shape when they receive the proper hose connections. When the new hose was sent, the wrong connections were provided with it.

I have a suggestion to make which, I think, will add to the safety of the children in the event of a fire taking place in this building. The top floor of the building provides a dormitory at each end. Each of these dormitories have access to the fire escapes, but there is no connection from one dormitory to the other, and in the event of fire at one end of the building cutting off access to the escapes, it would be impossible for them to pass to the other dormitory and use the escapes from there. It would be an easy matter to make an opening and put in a door between these dormitories. This could be properly secured, but would be available for use in case of emergency.

They have two chemical fire extinguishers on the first two floors of the building, but none on the top floor and none for the outbuildings. They should have at least six more extinguishers as a measure of safety.

The paint on the outside of the building is in bad shape. As I pointed out in my last report, it is scaling off badly.

LAUNDRY

The Sisters pointed out that although they have a soft water tank, they have no means of heating soft water in the laundry. They are using a small agricultural boiler now, the pipe from which is carried through a ventilator across the hall to a main chimney.
R. C. INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL (CONT'D.)

LAUNDRY (CONT'D.)

This does not look a very safe arrangement to me, and I think that a separate brick chimney should be built for the laundry. The brick for this chimney to be freighted by the school teams free of cost. They also pointed out that they have no drier for clothes, and they expressed a desire to have one. The laundry is equipped with four sett tubs, a washing machine and extractor.

The Sisters also asked that a wash basin and toilet be placed on the first floor for their private use. There was none provided when the building was built.

The dormitory beds are equipped with 110 hay ticks. The hay is changed once a year. The only smell noticeable in the building was the smell from the old hay in these ticks.

FARM

They have 170 acres ready for seed this spring; 60 acres of this will be sown to wheat and the balance to mixed feed grains. They have 12 milk cows, 9 of which are pure Ayrshire. They have 1 bull and 6 young heifers.

They raise about 50 hogs each year, but have had to cut down on account of having no accommodation for them. They have to keep the hogs in the barn owing to lack of room. There is an item in the Estimates for a piggery for this institution this year. There is also an item in the Estimates for a garage, but the Principal states that he would rather forego the garage this year in favour of more room for the live stock. They have only sixteen stalls in their barn, and the Principal states that if we could provide a lean-to shed to the barn, it would be
R. C. INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL (CONT'D.)

FARM (CONT'D.)

would be more useful to them than a garage.

They have six work horses and would like to get two more to enable them to make up two - four horse teams.

The cottage provided for the Farming Instructor at this school is a very neat building. It was wired for electric lights, but no fixtures were provided and the building was not connected with the system. They informed me that they could do the work if the Department would provide the fixtures and wire, which, it is estimated, would cost $75.00.

There is no ice house or refrigerator at this school and they have no means of keeping fresh meat during the summer months. As they have to bring their meat from Lloydminster, a distance of over 30 miles, it is impossible to keep it for more than a day or so during the warm weather.

The Rev. Father Therien is again in charge here, and the work of the school appears to go very smoothly and efficiently under his management.

Sir,

Reference your instructions of October 22nd, 1929, in connection with an inspection at the Onion Lake (R.C.) Indian School, Lloydminster, together with a report on the Church of England School also situated at Onion Lake.

An effort was made to carry out these instructions earlier in the year, but owing to the river crossing, this inspection was postponed till May 8th, 1930.

ONION LAKE (R.C.) INDIAN SCHOOL.

Date of inspection. May 8, 1930.

Purpose of Inspection. To ascertain if the new equipment which was ordered last August had been installed, and as to whether or not the water system is working satisfactorily.

The list of equipment which was forwarded in your instructions of October 22nd, was checked over in company with the Indian School engineer, and it was found that all the new equipment had been installed.

The engineer complained of the main drive belt in the engine house, constantly jumping off the pump pulley, as he stated that every time he started to pump water, this belt flew off. He was therefore unable to let any of the students run the plant, and he requested some means of maintaining the belt. I was of the opinion that the belt was used too tightly, and that if it was slackened a little bit, and possibly resin applied to the driving surface, this would solve the difficulty. I am further of the opinion that a belt drive guide with weights would effectually keep this belt on, at the same time giving the correct tension to the belt.

The pump and the engine appear to be functioning very well, and the engineer had no complaints to make about any of the machinery except the engine belt. The sewage disposal plant is working excellently and has given no trouble this winter.

In connection with this visit to the school, I would respectfully point out one defect that was noted. In the laundry room, there is no means of heating the soft water which is collected from the roof, and carried to a storage reservoir, so it is collected in pails and carried to the laundry room where it is heated upon a wood stove, chimney of said stove being carried in a ventilator shaft in lieu of a proper chimney. This constitutes a certain hazard and I would recommend that a proper chimney be built with an outlet from the roof of the laundry room.
In conclusion I would state that the condition of the water supply system is in first class shape, and is being well looked after in every detail.

Sir:

I may say that I forwarded recommendations in connection with the addition to the barn, ice house, and hog pen, together with an estimate of the cost of the three buildings on the 10th instant.

With reference to the arrangements for heating soft water, I may say that it is too bad that this was not foreseen when the building was being put up as arrangements at that time could have been carried out at much less expense than will be necessary now. In my opinion, it would not be feasible to heat soft water in the kitchen for the large amount of washing to be done in the laundry of a school of this size, and the only alternative now will be to build a chimney, the cost of material and labour for which should not exceed $100.00. With reference to the painting material required for the floors of the dining room, recreation rooms, and passages in the basement, this would appear to be necessary in order to keep down dust which accumulates through wear on the concrete floor.

With reference to the oil storage tank and pump, I estimate that this could be supplied at a cost not exceeding $200.00. I think that this is a very wise thing to buy, and the expenditure would be justified.

Dear Sir:

Referring to Commissioner Graham's letter regarding the inspection of all the joints in the wiring at the Church of England School - It would be necessary to take down every lighting fixture in the building to get at the taped joints in the ceiling outlet boxes. These boxes contain anywhere from two to four of these joints. It has been found that the wall switch boxes have also been used as junction boxes in some cases. This would mean that all of the wall switches would also have to be removed, in order to get at any joints that might be in these boxes behind the switches.

The work of inspecting all of these joints, removing the tapes to see that the joints were soldered, and then putting fresh tape on the joints would take almost as long as would be required to re-wire the building.

In Mr. Graham's letter, no mention is made of whether he wants anything done about the loop-in system of wiring, shown in the sketch enclosed with his letter. There is no doubt that this loop-in system is much superior to the system of wiring now in use as the wires in the loop-in system are continuous throughout the circuit, whereas the present system is composed of short lengths of wire joined together in each outlet box. If the loop-in system was used however, it would be necessary to purchase new wire, as the wire now in use in the building, would be in too short lengths to be used for the loop-in system. In view of the amount of work required to inspect the joints, as requested by Mr. Graham, would it be advisable to communicate with him before proceeding with this work.

Yours truly,

Sgd. E. Rotherham.
With reference to Department No. 118-1-5 of the 10th instant, in regard to the suggested form of inspection of the electrical wiring at the Onion Lake C. of E. Indian Residential School, I enclose copy of a letter received from Mr. E. Rotherham of Onion Lake in connection therewith.

In forwarding this the Indian Agent states Mr. Rotherham appears to think that this work is unnecessary, as he has already tested all the wiring and feels almost positive that there are no loose joints. Just before receipt of the Department's letter I had received information in response to my enquiries that proper fuses had not been installed in the first instance, those in use being altogether too large for the purpose, and had written to the Indian Agent, after consultation with an expert here, to arrange for the installation of the proper sizes of fuses. The same expert endorses the opinion of Mr. Rotherham that the carrying out of the suggestions made in the Department's letter of the 10th September would be unnecessary on the grounds that the wiring has been inspected and tested by a qualified man and is reported as satisfactory; that proper sized fuses are now or about to be installed, and that switches which were overloaded have been replaced by those of the proper size. In view of these reports, I am not prepared to recommend to the Department that any further inspections are necessary, as I am satisfied that all safeguards have been taken. I have, therefore, not further instructed the Indian Agent. If, in view of the information I now forward to the Department, it considers the suggested work should be done, I will arrange for it, but I consider, with the expert, that it will be an unnecessary expenditure.

Your obedient servant,

W. M. Graham,

Ottawa, 11th October, 1930.

Dear Major Kennedy,

I have before me your letter of the 22nd ultimo with enclosures on behalf of Messrs. Brown and Hudson, contractors for the erection of the Indian residential school on the Onion Lake Indian Reserve.

In reply I have to say that Mr. Brown's claim as set forth in Mr. Thorson's letter of the 15th August last is based on the fact as alleged that the school building was constructed upon a site other than that contemplated by Mr. Brown when he made his tender and it is intimated that Mr. Brown was misled into this matter, first, by the contract itself which designates the building as the "Indian Residential School at Onion Lake, Saskatchewan", second, by the letter from Mr. Lang Turner, Indian Agent at Onion Lake, and, third, by the information given to the representative sent to look over the ground for this building at the request of Mr. Brown.

With respect to the first matter of complaint, I have to point out that the notice calling for tenders for this building provides that tenders shall be addressed as follows: "Tender for St. Anthony's Indian Residential School on the Onion Lake Indian Reserve, Sask." The specifications on which Mr. Brown tendered refers to this building as "The St. Anthony's Indian Residential School on the Onion Lake Indian Reserve, Sask." Mr. Brown's tender was made and his offer accepted before the effect of the formal contract had been officially registered by the word "Saskatchewan" in the formal contract which designated this building as the Indian Residential School at Onion Lake, Sask. The latter is merely an abbreviation of the fuller description set forth in the specifications on which Mr. Brown had already tendered.

Major W.W. Kennedy, M.C., LL.B., M.P.,
Winnipeg, Man.
With respect to the second matter of complaint, Mr. Brown points out that on the second page of the specifications it is provided that "with reference to the site of the proposed building" contractors were to refer to Indian Agent Lang Turner. Pursuant to this direction Mr. Brown wrote to Mr. Lang Turner and received a reply stating that "the site for the new school is about thirty miles due north of Lloydminster". This description, or lack of description, of the site is quite significant. At the settlement known as Onion Lake, there is a postoffice by that name. If the site had been at that place, the simplest way of informing Mr. Brown of the location of the site would be for the Agent to say that it was at Onion Lake. The site, however, was not so designated. There was no mention of Onion Lake. The location as given by the Agent was only of a general character and could not have been intended by him or relied upon by Mr. Brown as defining the actual site on which the school was to be erected. No one could identify the site from such information. Nor could the Agent inform Mr. Brown as to the exact site by correspondence without a surveyor's plan of the portion of the reserve on which the school was to be built.

With reference to the third circumstance by which Mr. Brown claims to have been misled, I have to say that it shows that Mr. Brown did not rely on the information given in the letter from our Agent above referred to for the location of the site. Mr. Brown apparently did not visit the site to ascertain for himself the necessary particulars as provided by the specifications but made an arrangement with a firm to send a man to look over the ground on his behalf. It is said that this man was told at Onion Lake that the site was right beside the old school at Onion Lake. It is not alleged that this man was told by the Indian Agent. The Department can take no responsibility with respect to any information given to this man by anyone else as to the location of this site.

Agent Turner in his letter to Mr. Brown above referred to apparently volunteered some information or gave it on request from Mr. Brown, as to the availability of gravel, water and lumber. As Mr. Brown, in the specifications, was referred to the Agent for the location of the site only, and as Mr. Brown was requested to visit the site and ascertain the facts for himself, the Department can take no responsibility as to what correspondence passed between the Agent and Mr. Brown as to these matters. We are advised, however, that the information given by the Agent to Mr. Brown as to the availability...
of gravel, water and lumber at the site where the school was intended to be erected and was erected is substantially correct.

In view of the facts, as above set forth, I regret that I am unable to give favourable consideration to this claim.

I am returning your enclosures herewith.

Very truly yours,

(Minister's signature)

Onion Lake.

Dear Sir,

All the improvements granted this year to our school by the Department are nearing completion to our great satisfaction. But would you let me draw your attention to the heavy expenses that through special circumstances have accumulated against our budget in connection with those improvements? I know that it was understood that the freighting of all materiel would be done by the School; but most of it has to be drawn for 35 miles from Lloydminster and at a time when the children were away for their holidays, when the work on the farm was very pressing and taking all hands; so that we have been obliged to get outside help for the freighting of lumber, nails, bricks, cement, sand...

We have to pay to various persons for carrying lumber and sand an amount of $749.00; we owe to one man only, Mr. Percy Taylor $175.39. Of course I do not mention what we have done ourselves.

Is it unreasonable to expect that on account of the circumstances, the Department will back up and pay the extra expenses? I hereby do make an instant request for that purpose, trusting that you will kindly consider it and recommend it to the Department, and I hope this will be granted.

I am glad to have this opportunity to thank you and to thank the Department for all that has been done this year for our School, and I remain

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]

Principal.

Sir:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 23rd instant No. 115-8-5 with reference to an account of $200.00 which has recently been submitted to the Department, for freighting of material used in the erection of certain buildings at the Onion Lake R.C. Indian Residential School.

In reply I may say that I do not think the Department should pay this account. The resident Agent made it clear to me that the freighting could be done at the school and I believe it could have been done. I do not think the excuse offered by the Principal is a good one. I am of the opinion that he should be called upon to pay this $200.00 out of the school earnings. In addition to this he should be told that he had no authority to incur this expenditure without first taking the matter up with the Department or this office, unless he was prepared to meet it himself. Had he taken it up with this office he would certainly have been told that he would have to get the freighting done, and it would have been done.

I would judge from your letter that the Principal has been in communication with you regarding this matter. He should have passed any communication he had to make through the local Indian Agent, in my opinion. If he had done so the chances are the account would not have been forwarded.

Your obedient servant,

The Secretary
Dept. of Indian Affairs,

Dear Sir,

Following the conversation we had lately, I beg you to back up and forward to the Department the following requests:

1. We are in need of a cellar adjacent to the house with convenient access from the kitchen so that we may have at hand the sufficient quantity of potatoes and other vegetables for the winter, and keep in a cool place all preserves and other provisions. We will be very thankful if you can get appropriation for that. The digging should be about ten feet, and the material needed is: Cement around 60 bags; 2000 feet of lumber, and a few yards of galvanised iron.

2. Then, in the house on the walls in the public passages and up along the stairs a lining of burlap would be necessary to prevent the falling of plaster and keep it clean.

3. In the nurse's room is wanted a kind of combined glassed case and cupboard, 4 feet wide, where could be kept the most used medicines and accessories.

You have seen by yourself that these requests are very reasonable, and I trust that by your recommendation they will be granted.

Thanking you in advance, I remain

Yours very sincerely,

[Signature]
